editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: A pleasant conceited comedy, wherein is showed how a man may choose a good wife from a bad. As it hath been sundry times acted by the Earl of worcesters servants.
London printed for Mathew law, and are to be sold at his shop in Paul's churchyard, near unto s. Augustine's gate, at the sign of the fox. 1602.

div.head: A pleasant conceited comedy, wherein is showed how a man may choose a good wife from a bad.
div.stage: Enter as upon the exchange, young master Arthur, and master Lusam.

sp.speaker: Arthur.
sp.l: I tell you true sir, but to every man
I would not be so lavish of my speech,
Only to you my dear and private friend,
Although my wife in every eye, be held
Of beauty and of grace sufficient,
Of honest birth and good behaviour,
Able to win the strongest thoughts to her,
Yet in my mind I hold her the most hated
And loathed object that the world can yield.

sp.speaker: Lusam.
sp.l: O m. Arthur, bear a better thought
Of your chaste wife, whose modesty hath won
The good opinion and report of all:
By heaven you wrong her beauty, she is fair.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Not in mine eye.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: O you are cloyed with dainties m. Arthur
And too much sweetness glutted hath your taste,
And makes you loathe them: at the first
You did admire her beauty, praised her face,
Were proud to have her follow at your heels
Through the broad streets, when all censuring tongues
found themselves busied as she passed along,
To extol her in the hearing of you both,
Tell me I pray you and dissemble not,
Have you not in the time of your first love,
Hugged such new popular and vulgar talk,
And glorified still to see her bravely decked?
But now a kind of loathing hath quite changed
Your shape of love into a form of hate,
But on what reason ground you this hate?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My reason is my mind, my ground my will,
I will not love her: if you ask me why
I cannot love her, let that answer you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Be judge all eyes, her face deserves it not,
Then on what root grows this high branch of hate
Is she not loyal, constant, loving, chaste,
Obedient, apt to please, loath to displease,
Careful to live, chary of her good name,
And jealous of your reputation?
Is she not virtuous, wise, religious?
How should you wrong her to deny all this?
Good m. Arthur let me argue with you.

div.stage: Enter walking and talking, m. ansc●●●e, and master Futter.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: O m. Anselm, grown a lover, fie,
What might she be, on whom your hopes rely?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What fools they are that seem most wise in love,
How wise they are, that are but fools in love:
Before I was a lover, I had reason
To judge of matters, censure of all sorts,
Nay I had wit to call a lover fool,
And look into his folly with bright eyes,
But now intruding love dwells in my brain,
and frantically hath shouldered reason thence,
I am not old, and yet alas I dote:
I have not lost my sight, and yet am blind,
No bondman, yet have lost my liberty,
No natural fool, and yet I want my wit.
What am I then, let me define myself,
A dotard young, a blind man that can see,
A witty fool, a bondman that is free.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Good aged youth, blind seer, and wise fool,
Lose your free bonds, and set your thoughts to school.

div.stage: Enter old m. Arthur, and old m. Lusam.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis told me m. Lusam, that my son
And your chaste daughter whom we matched together,
Wrangle and fall at odds, and brawl, and chide.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Nay I think so, I never looked for better;
This 'tis to marry children when they are young,
I said as much at first, that such young brats
Would 'gree together, even like dogs and cats.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Nay pray you m. Lusam say not so,
There was great hope, though they were matched but young
Their virtues would have made then sympathize,
And live together like two quiet saints,

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: You say true, there was great hope indeed
They would have lived like saints, but where's the fault?

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: If fame be true, the most fault's in my son.

sp.speaker: Old. Lu.
sp.l: You say true m. Arthur, 'tis so indeed.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Nay sir, I do not altogether excuse
Your daughter, many lay the blame on her,

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Ha say you so, bithmasse 'tis like enough,
For from her childhood she hath been a shrew.

sp.speaker: Old Ar
sp.l: A shrew, you wrong her, all the town admires her,
For mildness, chasteness, and humility.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Fore God you say well, she is so indeed.
The city doth admire her for these virtues.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: O sir, you praise your child too palpably,
She's mild and chaste, but not admired so much.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I so I say, I did not mean admired.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Yes if a man do well consider her,
Your daughter is the wonder of her sex.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Are you advised of that, I cannot tell
What 'tis you call the wonder of her sex,
But she is, is she, I indeed she is.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: What is she?

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Even what you will, you know best what she is.

sp.speaker: Anselm.
sp.l: Yond is her husband, let us leave this walk,
How full are bad thoughts of suspicion;
I love, but loathe myself for loving so,
Yet cannot change my disposition.

sp.speaker: Fuller.
sp.l: Medice cure teipsum.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: Hei mihi quod mellis amor est medicabilis herbis .

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: All your persuasions are to no effect,
Never allege her virtues nor her beauty,
My settled unkindness hath begotten
A resolution to be unkind still,
My ranging pleasures love variety.

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: O too unkind unto so kind a wife,
Too virtueless to one so virtuous,
And too unchaste unto so chaste a matron.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: But soft sir, see where my two fathers are
Busily talking, let us shrink aside,
For if they see me, they are bent to chide.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I think 'tis best to go straight to the house
And make them friends again: what think you sir?

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I think so too.

sp.speaker: Old Arth.
sp.l: Now I remember too, that's not so good,
for divers reasons I think best stay here,
And leave them to their wrangling, what think you?

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I think so too.

sp.speaker: Old Arth.
sp.l: Nay we will go that's certain.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I 'tis best, 'tis best in sooth: there's no way but to go.

sp.speaker: Old Arth.
sp.l: Yet if our going should breed more unrest,
More discord, more dissension, more debate,
More wrangling where there is enough already,
'Twere better stay then go.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Fore God 'tis true,
Our going may perhaps breed more debate,
And then we may too late wish we had stayed:
And therefore if you will be ruled by me,
We will not go that's flat: nay if we love
Our credits, or our quiets, let's not go.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: But if we love their credits or their quiets we must go
And reconcile them to their former love:
Where there is strife betwixt a man and wife 'tis hell,
And mutual love may be compared to heaven:
For then their souls and spirits are at peace.
Come m. Lusam, now 'tis dinner time,
When we have dined, the first work we will make,
Is to decide their jars for pity's sake.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Welfare a good heart, yet are you advice,
Go said you m. Arthur, I will run,
To end these broils that discord hath begun.

div.stage: Enter mistress Arthur, and her man Pipkin.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ar.
sp.l: Come hither Pipkin, how chance you tread so softly?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: For fear of breaking mistress.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ar.
sp.l: Art thou afraid of breaking, how so?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Can you blame me mistress, I am cracked already.

sp.speaker: Mistress
sp.l: Cracked Pipkin, how, hath any cracked your crown?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: No mistress, I thank God my crown is currant, but.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: But what?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: The maid gave me not my supper yesternight, so that indeed my belly wambled; and standing near the great seacoal fire in the hall, and not being full, on the sudden I cracked, and you know mistress a pipkin is soon broken.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Sirrah run to the exchange, and if you there
Can find my husband, pray him to come home.
Tell him I will not eat a bit of bread
Until I see him: prithee Pipkin run.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: But lady mistress, if I should tell him so, it may be he would not come, were it for no other cause but to save charges, I'll rather tell him, if he come not quickly, you will eat up all the meat in the house, and then if he be of my stomach he will run every foot, and make the more hast to dinner.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: I thou mayst jest, my heart is not so light,
It can digest the least conceit of joy:
Entreat him fairly, though I think he loves
All places worse that he beholds me in,
Wilt thou be gone?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Whither mistress, to the change?

sp.speaker: Miss Ar.
sp.l: I to the change.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I will mistress, hoping my m. will go so oft to the change, that at length he will change his mind, and use you more kindly, o it were brave if my master could meet with a merchant of ill ventures to bargain with him for all his bad conditions, and he sell them outright, you should have a quieter heart, and we all a quieter house: but hoping mistress you will pass over all these jars and squabels in good health, as my master was at the making the thereof I commit you.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Make haste again I prithee, till I see him
My heart will never be at rest within me:
My husband hath of late so much estranged
His words, his deeds, his heart from me,
That I can seldom have his company:
And even that seldom with such discontent,
Such frowns, such chidings, such impatience,
That did not truth and virtue arm my thoughts,
They would confound me with despair and hate,
And make me run into extremities.
Had I deserved the least bad look from him,
I should account myself too bad to live,
But honouring him in love and chastity,
All judgements censure freely of my wrongs.

div.stage: Enter young Arthur, master Lusam, Pipkin.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Pipkin what said she when she sent for me?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Faith master she said little, but she thought more,
For she was very melancholy.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Did I not tell you she was melancholy?
For nothing else but that she sent for me,
And fearing I would come to dine with her.

sp.speaker: Yon. lus
sp.l: O you mistake her even upon my soul,
I durst affirm you wrong her chastity.
See where she doth attend your coming home.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Come master Arthur, shall we in to dinner?
Sirrah be gone, and see it served in.

sp.speaker: Yon. lus
sp.l: Will you not speak unto her?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: No not I, will you go in sir?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Not speak to me, nor once look towards me?
It is my duty to begin I know,
And I will break this ice of courtesy.
You are welcome home sir.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Hark master Lusam, if she mock me not,
you are welcome home sir, am I welcome home,
Good faith I care not if I be or no.

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: Thus you misconstrue all things m. Arthur,
Look if her true love melt not into tears.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: She weeps, but why? that I am come so soon
To hinder her of some appointed guests,
That in my absence revels in my house:
She weeps to see me in her company,
And were I absent, she would laugh with joy.
She weeps to make me weary of the house,
Knowing my heart cannot away with grief.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ar.
sp.l: Knew I that mirth would make you love my bed,
I would enforce my heart to be more merry.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Do you not hear, she would enforce her heart,
All mirth is forced that she can make with me.

sp.speaker: Young Lu.
sp.l: O misconceit, how bitter is thy taste?
Sweet m. Arthur, mistress Arthur too,
Let me entreat you reconcile these jars,
Odious to heaven, and most abhorred of men.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ar.
sp.l: You are a stranger sir, but by your words
You do appear an honest gentleman:
If you profess to be my husband's friend,
Persist in these persuasions: and be judge
With all indifference in these discontents.
Sweet husband, if I be not fair enough
To please your eye, range where you list abroad,
Only at coming home speak me but fair:
If you delight to change, change when you please,
So that you will not change your love to me.
If you delight to see me drudge and toil,
I'll be your drudge, because 'tis your delight.
Or if you think me unworthy of the name
Of your chaste wife, I will become your maid,
your slave, your servant, any thing you will,
If for that name of servant, and of slave,
You will but smile upon me now and then.
Or if as I well think you cannot love me,
Love where you list, only say but you love me:
I'll feed on shadows let the substance go.
Will you deny me such a small request?
What will you neither love nor flatter me?
O then I see your hate here doth but wound me,
And with that hate it is your frowns confound me.

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: Wonder of women: why hark you m. Arthur,
What is your wife a woman or a saint?
A wife, or some bright angel come from heaven?
Are you not moved at this strange spectacle?
This day I have beheld a miracle.
When I attempt this sacred nuptial life,
I beg of heaven to find me such a wife.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, a miracle, a prodigy,
To see a woman weep is as much pity
As to see foxes digged out of their holes:
If thou wilt pleasure me, let me see thee less,
Grieve much: they say grief often shortens life,
Come not too near me, till I call he wife.
And that will be but seldom, I will tell thee
How thou shalt win my heart, die suddenly,
And I'll become a lusty widower:
The longer thy life lasts the more my hate,
And loathing still increaseth towards thee.
When I come home and find thee cold as earth,
Then will I love thee: thus thou knowest my mind.
Come m. Lusam, let us in to dine.

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: O sir, you too much affect this evil,
Poor saint, why wert thou yoked thus with a devil.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: If thou wilt win my heart, die suddenly,
But that my soul was bought at such a rate,
At such a high price as my saviour's blood,
I would not stick to lose it with a stab.
But virtue banish all such fantasies.
He is my husband, and I love him well,
Next to my own soul's health I tender him:
And would give all the pleasures of the world,
To buy his love if I might purchase it.
I'll follow him, and like a servant wait,
And strive by all means to prevent his hate.

div.stage: Enter old Arthur, and old lusam.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: This is my son's house, were it best go in,
How say you master Lusam?

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: How go in, how say you sir?

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I say 'tis best.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: Ay sir, say you so, so say I too.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Nay, nay, it is not best, I'll tell you why,
Happily the fire of hate is quite extinct
From the dead embers, now to rake them up,
Should the least spark of discontent appear,
To make the flame of hatred burn a fresh,
The heat of this dissension might scorch us,
Which in his own cold ashes smothered up,
May die in silence, and revive no more:
And therefore tell me, is it best or no?

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: How say you sir?

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I say it is not best.

sp.speaker: Old. lus
sp.l: Mass you say well sir, and so say I too.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: But shall we lose our labour to come hither,
And without sight of our two children?
Go back again, nay we will in that's certain.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: In quotha, do you make a doubt of that?
Shall we come thus far, and in such post haste,
And have our children here and both within,
And not behold them ere our back return?
It were unfriendly, and unfatherly:
Come m. Arthur, pray you follow me.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Nay but hark you sir, will you not knock?

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Is't best to knock?

sp.speaker: Old. Ar.
sp.l: I knock in any case.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: 'Twas well you put it in mind to knock,
I had forgotten it else I promise you.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Tush, is't not my sons and your daughter's door,
And shall we two stand knocking? Lead the way.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Knock at our children's doors, that were a jest,
Are we such fools to make ourselves so strange
Where we should still be boldest? In for shame.
We will not stand upon such ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Speak in what cue sir do you find your heart,
Now thou hast slept a little on thy love?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Like one that strives to shun a little plash
Of shallow water, and avoiding it,
Plunges into a river passed his depth.
Like one that from a small spark steps aside,
And falls in headlong to a greater flame:

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: But in such fires scorch not thyself for shame.
If she be fire, thou art so far from burning,
That thou hast scarce yet warmed thee at her face
But list to me, I'll turn thy heart from love,
And make thee loathe all of the feminine sex.
They that have known me, knew me once of name
To be a perfect wencher: I have tried
All sorts, all sects, all states, and find them still
Inconstant, fickle, always variable.
Attend me man, I will prescribe a method
How thou shalt win her without all peradventure,

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: That would I gladly hear.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I was once like thee,
A fighter, melancholy, humorist,
Crosser of arms, a goer without garters,
A hatband-hater, and a busk-point wearer,
One that did use much bracelets made of hair,
Rings on my fingers, jewels in mine ears,
And now and then a wench's carcanet,
That had two letters for her name in pearl:
Scarves, garters, bands, wrought waistcoats, gold, stitched caps,
A thousand of those female fooleries,
But when I looked into the glass of reason, straight I began
To loathe that female bravery, and henceforth
Study to cry peccavi to the world.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I pray you to your former argument,
Prescribe a means to win my best beloved.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: First be not bashful, bar all blushing tricks,
Be not too apish female, do not come
With foolish sonnets to present her with,
With legs, with courtesies, congees, and such like:
Nor with penned speeches, or too far fetched sighs,
I hate such antic quaint formality.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O but I cannot watch occasion,
She dashes every proffer with a frown.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: A frown, a fool art thou afraid of frowns?
He that will leave occasion for a frown,
Were I his judge (All you his case bemoan)
His doom should be, ever to lie alone.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I cannot choose but when a wench says nay,
To take her at her word and leave my suit.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Continue that opinion, and be sure
To die a virgin chaste, a maiden pure.
It was my chance once in my wanton days
To court a wench, hark and I'll tell thee how:
I came unto my love, and she looked coy,
I spoke unto my love, she turned aside,
I touched my love, and 'gan with her to toy,
But she sat mute for anger, or for pride:
I strived and kissed my love, she cried away:
Thou wouldst have left her thus, I made her stay.
I catched my love, and wrung her by the hand,
I took my love and set her on my knee,
And pulled her to me, o you spoil my band,
You hurt me sir, pray let me go quoth she.
I am glad quoth I, that you have found your tongue,
And still my love I by the finger wrong.
I asked her if she loved me, she said no,
I bade her swear, she straight calls for a book:
Nay then thought I, 'tis time to let her go,
I eased my knee, and from her cast a look,
She leaves me wondering at these strange affairs,
And like the wind she trips me up the stairs.
I left the room below and up I went,
Finding her thrown upon her wanton bed:
I asked the cause of her sad discontent,
Further she lies, and making room she said,
Now sweeting kiss me, having time and place:
So clings me too her with a sweet embrace.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Is't possible, I had not thought till now
That women could dissemble. M. Fuller
Here dwells the sacred mistress of my heart,
Before her door I'll frame a frivolous walk,
And spying her, with her device some talk.

div.stage: Enter as out of the house, m. Arthur, mistress Arthur, old Arthur, old Lusam, young Lusan, Pipkin, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What stir is this, let's step but out the way
And hear the utmost what these people say.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Thou art a knave, although thou be my son,
Have I with care and trouble brought thee up,
To be a staff and comfort to my age,
A pillar to support me, and a crutch
To lean on in my second infancy,
And dost thou use me thus? thou art a knave.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: A knave, I marry, and an arrant knave:
And sirrah, by old m. Arthur's leave,
Though I be weak and old, I'll prove thee one.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Sir, though it be my father's pleasure thus
To wrong me with the scorned name of knave,
I will not have you so familiar,
Nor so presume upon my patience.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Speak m. Arthur, is he not a knave?

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I say he is a knave.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Then so say I.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: My father may command my patience,
But you sir that are but my father in law,
Shall not so mock my reputation,
Sir you shall find I am an honest man.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: An honest man.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Ay sir, so I say.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Nay if you say so, I'll not be against it;
But sir you might have used my daughter better,
Than to have beat her, spurned her, railed at her
Before our faces.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I therein son Arthur,
Thou show'dst thyself no better than a knave.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I marry did he, I will stand to it,
To use my honest daughter in such sort,
He showed himself no better than a knave.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I say again I am an honest man,
He wrongs me that shall say the contrary.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I grant sir that you are an honest man,
nor will I say unto the contrary.
But wherefore do you use my daughter thus?
Can you accuse her of inchastity,
Of loose demeanour, disobedience, or disloyalty?
Speak what thou canst thou object against my daughter.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Accuse her, here she stands, spit in her face
If she be guilty in the least of these.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: O father be more patient, if you wrong
My honest husband, all the blame be mine,
Because you do it only for my sake.
I am his handmaid, since it is his pleasure
To use me thus, I am content therewith,
And bear his checks and crosses patiently.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: If in mine own house I can have no place,
I'll seek it elsewhere, and frequent it less,
Father I am now passed one and twenty years,
I am past my father's pampering, I suck not:
Nor am I dandled on my mother's knee:
Then if you were my father twenty times,
You shall not choose but let me be myself.
Do I come home so seldom, and that seldom
Am I thus baited? Wife remember this.
Father farewell, and father in law adieu:
Your son had rather fast, than feast with you.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Well go too wild oats, spend thrift, prodigal,
I'll cross thy name quite from my reckoning book:
For these accounts, faith it shall scathe thee somewhat,
I will not say what somewhat it shall be.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: And it shall scathe him somewhat of my purse,
And daughter I will take thee home again,
Since thus he hates thy fellowship,
Be such an eyesore to his sight no more,
I tell thee thou no more shalt trouble him.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Will you divorce whom God hath tied together?
Or break that knot the sacred hand of heaven
Made fast betwixt us? Have you never read
What a great curse was laid upon his head
That breaks the holy band of marriage,
Divorcing husbands from their chosen wives?
Father I will not leave my Arthur so,
Not all my friends can make me prove his foe.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I could say somewhat in my son's reproof,

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Faith so could I.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: But till I meet him I will let it pass.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Faith so will I.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Daughter farewell, with weeping eyes I part,
Witness these tears, thy grief sus near my heart.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Weeps m. Arthur, nay then let me cry:
His cheeks shall not be wet, and mine be dry.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ar.
sp.l: Fathers farewell, spend not a tear for me:
But for my husband's sake let these woes be.
For when I weep, 'tis not for my own care,
But fear least folly bring him to despair.

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: Sweet saint continue still this patience,
For time will bring him to true penitence.
Mirror of virtue, thanks for my good cheer,
A thousand thanks.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ar.
sp.l: It is so much too dear,
But you are welcome for my husband's sake,
His guests shall have best welcome I can make.

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: Then marriage, nothing in the world more common,
Nothing more rare than such a virtuous woman.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: My husband in this humour, well I know
Plays but the unthrift, therefore it behoves me
To be the better housewife here at home,
To save and get, whilst he doth laugh and spend:
Though for himself he riots it anlarge,
My needle shall defray my households charge.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Now m. Anselm to her, step not back,
Busy yourself, see where she sits at work:
Be not afraid man, she's but a woman,
And women, the most cowards seldom fear:
Think but upon my former principles,
And twenty pound to a dream you speed.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Ay, say you so?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Beware of blushing sirrah,
Of fear and too much eloquence:
Rail on her husband his misusing her,
And make that serve thee as an argument,
That she may sooner yield to do him wrong:
Were it my case, my love and I to plead,
I have't at singer's ends, who could miss the clout
Having so fair a white, such steady aim,
This is the upshot, now bid for the game.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Fair mistress God save you.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What a circumstance doth he begin with, what an ass is he
To tell her at the first that she was fair?
The only means to make her to be coy:
He should have rather told her she was foul,
And brought her out of love quite with herself:
And being so, she would the less have cared
Upon whose secrets she had laid her love:
He hath almost marred all with that word fair.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Mistress God save you.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What a block is that
To say God save you, is the fellow mad,
Once to name God in his ungodly suit?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: You are welcome sir. Come you to speak with me,
Or with my husband, pray you what's your will?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: She answers to the purpose, what's your will?
O 'zounds that I were there to answer her.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Mistress my will is not so soon expressed,
without your special favour, and the promise
Of love and pardon if I speak amiss.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: O ass, o Duns, o blockhead that hath left
The plain broad high way, and the readiest path
To travel round about by circumstance:
He might have told his meaning in a word,
And now hath lost his opportunity:
Never was such a truant in love's school,
I am ashamed that ere I was his tutor.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Sir you may freely speak whate'er it be,
So that your speech suiteth with modesty.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: To this now could I answer passing well.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Mistress I pitying that so fair a creature.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Still fair, and yet I warned the contrary.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Should by a villain be so foully used as you have been.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I that was well put in,
If time and place were both convenient.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Have made this bold intrusion to present
My love and service to your sacred self.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Indifferent, that was not much amiss.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Sir, what you mean by service and by love
I will not know: but what you mean by villain
I fain would know.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: That villain is your husband:
Whose wrongs towards you, are bruited thorough the land.
O can you suffer at a peasant's hands
Unworthy once to touch this silken skin,
To be so rudely beat and buffeted?
Can you endure from such infectious breath
Able to blast your beauty, to have names
Of such empoisoned hate flung in your face?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: O that was good, nothing was good but that:
That was the lesson that I taught him last.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O can you hear your never tainted fame
wounded with words of shame and infamy?
O can you see your pleasures dealt away,
And you to be debarred all part of them,
And bury it in deep oblivion?
Shall your true right be still contributed
Amongst hungry bawds, insatiable courtesans?
And can you love that villain by whose deed
Your soul doth sigh, and your distressed heart bleed?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: All this as well as I could wish myself.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Sir I have heard thus long with patience,
If it be me you term a villain's wife,
Insooth you have mistook me all this while,
And neither know my husband nor myself,
Or else you know not man and wife is one:
If he be called a villain, what is she
Whose heart, and love, and soul, is one with him?
'Tis pity that so fair a gentleman
Should fall into such villain's company.
O sir take heed, if you regard your life,
Meddle not with a villain, or his wife.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: O that same word villain hath marred all.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Now where is your instruction? where's the wench?
Where are my hopes? where your directions?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Why man, in that word villain you marred all.
To come unto an honest wife and call
Her husband villain, were she ne'er so bad,
Thou mightst well think she would not brook that name
For her own credit, though no love to him.
But leave not thus, but try some other mean,
Let not one way thy hopes make frustrate clean.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I must persist my love against my will,
He that knows all things, knows I prove this ill.

div.stage: Enter Aminadab with a rod in his hand, and two or three boys with their books in their hands.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Come boys, come boys, rehearse your parts
And then ad prandium tamiam incipe.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Forsooth my lessons torn out of my book.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Que caceris chartis deservisse decat,
Torn from your book, I'll tear it from your breech,
How say you mistress Virga, will you suffer
Hic pver bone indolu, to tear
His lessons, eaves and lectures from his book?

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Truly forsooth I laid it in my seat
While Robin glade and I went into Campis:
And when I came again my book was torn.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: O must a mouse, was ever heard the like?

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: O domus a house, m. I could not mend it.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: O pediculus a louse, I knew not how it came.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: All towards boys, good scholars of their times,
The least of these is passed his accidence,
Some at qui mihi, here's not a boy
But he can construe all the grammar rules,
Said ubi sunt soledes, not yet come:
Those tarde vementes, shall be whipped.
Ubi est Pikin, where's that lazy knave?
He plays the truant every Saturday:
But mistress Virga, lady Willowby
Shall teach him that dilucoli surgere,
Est saluberrimum, here comes the knave.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.l: Tarde, tarde, tarde.

sp.speaker: 2. Boy.
sp.l: Tarde, tarde, tarde.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Huc ades Pipkin, reach a better rod,
Cur tam tarde vemo, speak, where have you been?
Is this a time of day to come to school?
Ubi finisti, speak, where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Magister, quomodo vales.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Is that responsio fitting my demand?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Etiam certain, you ask me where I have been, and I say Quomodo vales, as much to say, come out of the alehouse.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Untruss, untruss, nay help him, help him.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Queso preceptor, queso? for god's sake do not whip me:
Quidest gramatica?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Not whip you, quidest gramatica, what's that?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Gramatica est, that if I untrust, you must needs whip me upon them, quidest gramatica.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Why then dic mihi, speak, where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Forsooth my mistress sent me of an errant to fetch my m. from the exchange, we had strangers at home at dinner, and but for them I had not come tarde queso preceptor.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Construe your lesson, pierce it, ad ungem et condemnato, to I'll pardon thee.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: That I will m. and if you'll give me leave.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Propriaabque; maribus tribuuntur mascula dicas expone, expone.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Conster it m. I will, dicas they say, propria the proper man, que maribus, that loves marrowbones, mascula, miscalled me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: A pretty quaint and new construction.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I warrant you m. if there be mary bones in my lesson, I am an old dog at them. How construe you this m. Rostra disertus amat?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Disertus a disert, amat doth love, rostra, roast-meat.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: A good construction on an empty stomach, m. now I have constered my lesson, my mistress would pray you to let me come home to go of an errand.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Your tres sequntur, and away.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Canis a hog, rana a dog, porcus a frog,
Abeundum est mihi.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Yours sirrah to then, and ad prandium.

sp.speaker: 1. Boy.
sp.p: Apis a-bed , ge●●k●ee, vulcanus doctor dee? Figinti minus usus est mihi.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: By Ju●os's lip, and 〈◊〉 thumb
It was bonus, bona, bonum.

sp.speaker: 2. Bay.
sp.p: Vitrum glass, spica grass, tu es asinus, you are an ass, precor tibi felicem noctem.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Claudite iam libros pueri sat prate bibistis,
Look when you come again, you tell me ubi fuistis.
He that minds trish trash, and will not have care of his rodix,
He I will be lish lash, and have a fling at his podex.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: A pretty wench, a passing pretty wench,
A sweeter duck all London cannot yield,
She cast a glance on me as I passed by,
Not Helen had so ravishing an eye.
Here is the pedant sir Aminadab,
I will inquire of him if he can tell
By any circumstance whose wife she:
Such fellows commonly have intercourse
Without suspicion, where we are debarred.
God save you gentle sir Aminadab.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Salve tu quoq.;, would you speak with me?
You are I take it, and let me not lie,
For as you know, mentirinon est meum,
Young m. Arthur, quid vis, what will you?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: You are a man I much rely upon:
There is a pretty wench dwells in this street,
That keeps no shop, nor is not public known:
At the two posts, next turning of the lane,
I saw her from a window looking out:
Oh could you tell me how to come acquainted
With that sweet lass, you should command me sir,
Even to the utmost of my life and power.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Dij boni, boni, 'tis my love he means,
But I will keep it from this gentleman,
And so I hope make trial of my love.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: If I obtain her, thou shalt win thereby,
More than at this time I will promise thee.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Quando venis aput, I shall have two horns on my caput.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: What if her husband come and find one there?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Nuncquam, time never fear,
She is unmarried I swear.
But if I help you to the deed,
Tu vis narrare, how you speed.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Tell how I speed, I sir I will to you:
Then presently about it. Many thanks
For this great kindness sir Aminadab.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: If my puella prove a drab
I'll be revenged on both: ambo shall die,
Shall die by what, for ego I
Have never handled I thank God,
Other weapon than a rod:
I dare not fight for all my speeches,
Said cave, if I take him thus
Ego sum expers at untruss.

div.stage: Enter justice reason, old Arthur, old Lusam, mistress Arthur, young Lusam, and Hugh.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: We master justice reason come about
A serious matter that concerns us near.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I marry doth it sir concern us near:
Would god sir you would take some order for it.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Why look ye m. Lusam, you are such another
You will be talking, what concerns us near,
And know not why we come to m. justice.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: How, know not I?

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: No sir not you.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Well I know somewhat, though I know not that,
Then on I pray you.

sp.speaker: Just.
sp.l: Forward I pray, yet the case is plain.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Why sir as yet you do not know the case.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Well he knows somewhat, forward m. Arthur.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: And as I told you, my unruly son
Once having bid his wife home to my house,
There took occasion to be much aggrieved
About some household matters of his own,
And in plain terms they fell in controversy.

sp.speaker: Ol. Lu.
sp.l: 'Tis true sir, I was there the selfsame time,
And I remember many of the words.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Lord what a man are you, you were not there
That time, as I remember you were rid
Down to the North, to see some friends of yours.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Well I was somewhere, forward m. Arthur.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: All this is well, no fault is to be found
In either of the parties, pray say on.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Why sir I have not named the parties yet,
Nor touched the fault that is complained upon.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Well you touched somewhat: forward m. Arthur.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: And as I said, they fell in controversy:
My son not like a husband gave her words
Of great reproof, despite, and contumely.
Which she poor soul digested patiently:
This was the first time of their falling out.
As I remember at the self same time
One Thomas the Earl of Surrey's gentleman
Dined at my table.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: O I knew him well.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: You are the strangest man, this gentleman
That I speak of, I am sure you never saw,
He came but lately from beyond the sea.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I am sure I know one Thomas, forward sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: And is this all? make me a minimus,
And fend the offender straightways to the gale.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: First know the offender, how began the strife
Betwixt this gentlewoman and my son,
Since when sir he hath used her not like one
that should partake his bed, but like a slave.
My coming was, that you being in office
And in authority, should call before you
My unthrift son, to give him some advice,
Which he will take better from you, then me
That am his father. Here's the gentlewoman
Wife to my son, and daughter to this man,
Whom I perforce compelled to live with us.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: All this is well, here is your son you say,
But she that is his wife you cannot find.

sp.speaker: Young Lu.
sp.l: You do mistake sir, here's the gentlewoman,
It is her husband that will not be found.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Well all is one, for man and wife are one:
But is this all?

sp.speaker: Young Lu.
sp.l: I all that you can say,
And much more than you can well put off.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Nay if the case appear thus evident,
Give me a cup of wine, what man and wife
To disagree, I prithee fill my cup:
I could say somewhat, tut, tut, by this wine,
I promise you, 'tis good canary sack.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Fathers you do me open violence
To bring my name in question, and produce
This gentleman and others here to witness
My husband's shame in open audience:
What may my husband think when he shall know
I went unto the justice to complain:
But m. justice here more wise than you,
Says little to the matter, knowing well
His office is no whit concerned herein:
Therefore with favour I will take my leave.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: The woman saith but reason m. Arthur,
And therefore give her licence to depart.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Here is dry justice not to bid us drink,
hark thee my friend, I prithee lend thy cup:
Now m. justice hear me but one word,
You think this woman hath had little wrong?
But by this wine which I intend to drink.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Nay save your oath, I pray you do not swear,
Or if you swear, take not too deep an oath.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Content you, I may take a lawful oath
Before a justice: therefore by this wine.

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: A profound oath, well sworn, and deeply took,
'Tis better thus, then swearing on a book.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: My daughter hath been wronged exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: O sir, I would have credited these words
Without this oath: but bring your daughter hither,
That I may give her counsel ere you go.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Marry God's blessing on your heart for that,
Daughter give ear to justice reasons words.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Good woman, or good wife, or mistress, if you have done amiss, it should seem you have done a fault; and making a fault, there's no question but you have done amiss: but if you walk uprightly, and neither lead to the right hand nor the left, no question but you have neither led to the right hand nor the left, but as a man should say, walked uprightly: but it should appear by these plaintiffs, that you have had some wrong, if you love your spouse entirely, it should seem you affect him fervently; and if he hate you monstrously, it should seem he loathes you most exceedingly: and there's the point, at which I will leave, for the time passes away: therefore to conclude, this is my best counsel, look that thy husband so fall in, that hereafter you never fall out.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Good counsel, passing good instruction,
Follow it daughter. Now I promise you,
I have not heard such an oration
This many a day: what remains to do?

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: Sir I was called as witness to this matter,
I may be gone for ought that I can see.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Nay stay my friend, we must examine you,
What can you say concerning this debate
Betwixt young m. Arthur and his wife?

sp.speaker: Young Lu.
sp.l: Faith just as much I think as you can say
And that's just nothing.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: How nothing? come depose him, take his oath,
Swear him I say, take his confession.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: What can you say sir in this doubtful case?

sp.speaker: Young Lu.
sp.l: Why nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: We cannot take him in contrary tales,
For he says nothing still, and that same nothing
Is that which we have stood on all this while:
He hath confessed even all, for all is nothing.
This is your witness, he hath witnessed nothing.
Since nothing then so plainly is confessed,
And we by cunning answers and by wit
Have wrought him to confess nothing to us,
Write his confession.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Why what should we write?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Why nothing: heard you not as well as I
What he confessed? I say write nothing down.
Mistress we have dismissed you, love your husband,
Which whilst you do, you shall not hate your husband.
Bring him before me, I will urge him with
This gentleman's express confession
Against you: send him to me, I'll not fail
To keep just nothing in my memory.
And sir now that we have examined you,
We likewise here discharge you with good leave.
Now m. Arthur, and m. Lusam too,
Come in with me, unless the man were here
Whom most especially the cause concerns,
we cannot end this quarrel: but come near,
And we will taste a glass of our march beer.

div.stage: Enter mistress Mary, mistress Splay and Brabo.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: I prithee tell me Brabo, what planet thinkst thou governed at my conception, that I live thus openly to the world?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Two planets reigned at once, Venus that's you,
And Mars that's I, were in conjunction.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.p: Prithee, prithee, in faith that conjunction copulative, is that part of speech that I live by.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ha, ha, to see the world, we swaggerers
That live by oaths and big-mouthed menaces,
Are now reputed for the tallest men:
He that hath now a black moustache
Reaching from ear to ear, or turning up
Puncto reverso, bristling towards the eye:
He that can hang two handsome tools at his side,
Go in disguised attire, wear iron enough,
Is held a tall man and a soldier.
He that with greatest grace can swear gog's zounds,
Or in a tavern make a drunken fray,
Can cheat at dice, swagger in bawdy houses,
Wear velvet on his face, and with a grace
Can face it out with as I am a soldier.
He that can clap his sword upon the board
He's a brave man, and such a man am I.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: She that with kisses can both kill and cure,
That lives by love, that swears by nothing else
But by a kiss, which is no common oath:
That lives by lying, and yet oft tells truth;
That takes most pleasure when she takes most pains:
She's a good wench my boy, and such am I.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: She that is past it, and prays for them that may.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Is an old bawd as you are mistress splay.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: O do not name that name, do you not know
That I could never endure to hear that name.
But if your man would leave us, I would read
The lesson that last night I promised you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I prithee leave us, we would be alone.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: And will and must: if you bid me be gone,
I will withdraw, and draw on any he
That in the world's wide round dare cope with me.
Mistress farewell, to none I never speak
So kind a word. My salvations are,
Farewell and be hanged, or in the devil's name.
What they have been my many frays can tell,
You cannot fight therefore to you farewell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O this same swaggerer is the bulwark of my reputation
But mistress splay, now to your lecture that you promised me:

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: Daughter attend, for I will tell thee now
What in my young days I myself have tried:
Be ruled by me and I will make thee rich.
You God be praised are fair, and as they say
Full of good parts, you have been often tried
To be a woman of good carriage,
Which in my mind is very commendable.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It is indeed. Forward good mother splay.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: And as I told you, being fair, I wish
Sweet daughter you were as fortunate.
When any suitor comes to ask thy love,
Look not into his words, but into his sleeve.
If thou canst learn what language his purse speaks,
Be ruled by that, that's golden eloquence.
Money can make a slavering tongue speak plain.
If he that loves thee be deformed and rich,
Accept his love, gold hides deformity.
Gold can make limping Vulcan walk upright,
Make squint eyes look straight, a crabbed face look smooth,
guilds copernoses, makes them look like gold.
Fills ages wrinkles up and makes a face
As old as Nestor's, look as young as Cupid's.
If thou wilt arm thyself against all shifts,
Regard all men according to their gifts.
This if thou practise, thou when I am dead
Wilt say old mother splay soft laid thy head.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Soft who comes here? begone good mistress splay,
Of thy rules practise this is my first day.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: God for thy passion what a beast am I,
To scar the bird that to the net would fly.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: By your leave mistress.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What to do master?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: To give me leave to love you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I had rather afford you some love to leave me.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: I would you would as soon love me, as I could leave you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I pray you what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: A man I'll assure you.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How should I know that?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Try me by my word, for I say I am a man,
Or by my deed, I'll prove myself a man.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Are you not master Arthur?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Not m. Arthur, but Arthur, and your servant sweet mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Not mistress Mary, but Mary and your handmaid, sweet master Arthur.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.p: That I love you, let my face tell you: that I love you more than ordinarily, let this kiss testify: and that I love you fervently and entirely, ask this gift, and see what it will answer you. Myself, my purse, and all being wholly at your service.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p:
That I take your love in good part, my thanks shall speak for me: that I am pleased with your kiss, this
interest of another shall certify you: and that I accept your gift, my prostrate service and self shall witness with me. My love, my lips, and sweet self, are at your service: wilt please you to come near sir?

sp.speaker: Yon. Lu.
sp.l: O that my wife were dead, here would I make
My second choice, would she were buried,
From out her grave this marigold should grow,
Which in my nuptials I would wear with pride.
Die shall she, I have doomed her destiny.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: 'Tis news m. Arthur to see you in such a place,
How doth your wife?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Faith mistress Mary at the point of death,
And long she cannot live, she shall not live
To trouble me in this my second choice.

div.stage: Enter Aminadab with a bill and head-piece.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I pray forbear sir, for here comes my love,
Good sir for this time leave me: by this kiss
You cannot ask the question at my hands
I will deny you: pray you get you gone.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Farewell sweet mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sweet adieu:

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Stand to me bill, and head-piece sit thou close,
I hear my love, my wench, my duck, my dear,
Is sought by many suitors, but with this
I'll keep the door, and enter he that dare.
Virga be gone, thy twigs I'll turn to steel,
These fingers that were expert in the jerk,
In steed of lashing of the trembling podes,
Must learn pash and knock, and beat and maul,
Cleave pates, and caputs he that enters here
Comes on his death, mors mort, is he shall taste.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Alas poor fool, the pedants mad for love,
Thinks me more mad that I would marry him:
He's come to watch me with a rusty bill,
to keep my friends away by force of arms,
I will not see him but stand still aside,
And here observe him what he means to do.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: O utinam, that he that loves her best
Durst offer but to touch her in this place.
Per Jehova, et junonem hoc,
Shall pash his coxcomb such a knock,
As that his soul his course shall take
To limbo, and Avernus' lake.
In vain I watch in this dark hole,
Would any living durst my manhood try,
And offer to come up the stairs this way.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O we should see you make a goodly fray.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: The wench I here watch with my bill,
Amo, amas, amavi still.
Qui audet let him come that dare,
Death, hell, and limbo be his share.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Where's mistress Mary, never a post here,
A bar of iron 'gainst which to try my sword?
Now by my beard a dainty piece of steel.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: O Jove what a qualm is this I feel?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Come hither Mall, is none here but we two?
When didst thou see the starveling schoolmaster?
sp.p: That rat, that shrimp, that spindleshank, that wren, that sheep-biter, that lean chittiface, that famine, that lean envy, that all bones, that bare anatomy, that Jack a Lent, that ghost, that shadow, that moon in the wane.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: I wail in woe, I plunge in pain.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: When next I find him here I'll hang him up
Like a dried sausage, in the chimney's top:
That stockfish, that poor John, that gut of men.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: O that I were at home again.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: When he comes next turn him into the streets,
now come let's dance the shaking of the sheets.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Qui que quod, hence boisterous bill, come gentle rod.
Had not grim malkin stamped and stared,
Aminadab had little cared:
Or if in stead of this brown bill,
I had kept my mistress Virga still,
And he upon another's back,
His points untrust, his breeches slack:
My countenance he should not dash,
For I am expert in the lash.
But my sweet lass my love doth fly,
Which shall make me by poison die.
Perfidem, I will rid my life,
Either by poison, sword, or knife.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Sirrah when saw you your master?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Faith mistress when I last looked upon him.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: And when was that?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: When I beheld him.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ar.
sp.l: And when was that?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Marry when he was in my sight, and that was yesterday, since when I saw not my master, nor looked on my m. nor beheld my master, nor had any sight of my m.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Was he not at my father in laws?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Yes marry was he.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Didst thou not entreat him to come home?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: How should I mistress, he came not there today.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Didst not thou say he was there?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: True mistress he was there, but I did not tell ye when,
He hath been there divers times, but not of late.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: About your business, here I'll sit and wait
His coming home, though it be ne'er so late.
Now once again go look him at the change,
Or at the church with sir Aminadab,
'tis told me they use often conference:
When that is done, get you to school again.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I had rather play the truant at home, then go seek my m. at school: let me see what age am I, some four and twenty, and how have I profited, I was five year learning to criss cross from great A. and five year longer coming to F. I there I stuck some three year before I could come to q. and so in process of time I came to e pierce e, and comperce, and tittle, than I got to a. e. i. o. u. after to our father, and in the sixteenth year of my age, and the fifteenth of my going to school, I am in good time gotten to a noun, by the same token there my hose went down: than I got to a verb, there I began first to have a beard: then I came to iste, ista, istud, there my m. whipped me till he fetched the blood, and so forth: so that now I am come the greatest scholar in the school: for I am bigger than two or three of them. But I am gone, farewell mistress.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Love none at all, they will forswear themselves,
And when you urge them with it, their replies
Are, that Jove laughs at lover's perjuries.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: You told me of a jest concerning that,
I prithee let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: That thou shalt.
My mistress in an humour had protested,
That above all the world she loved me best,
Saying with suitors she was oft molested,
And she had lodged her heart within my breast:
And sware (But me) both by her mask and fan,
She never would so much as name a man.
Not name a man quoth I, yet be advised,
Not love a man but me, let it be so:
You shall not think quoth she my thoughts disguised,
in flattering language, or dissembling show:
I say again, and I know what I do,
I will not name a man alive but you.
Into her house I came at unaware,
Her back was to me and I was not seen,
I stole behind her till I had her fair,
Then with my hands I closed both her eyne,
She blinded thus, beginneth to bethink her
Which of her loves it was that did hoodwink her,
First she begins to guess and name a man
That I well known, but she had known far better.
The next I never did suspect till than:
Still of my name I could not hear a letter,
Then mad, she did name Robin, and then James,
Till she had reckoned up some twenty names,
At length when she had counted up her score,
As one among the rest she hit on me:
I asked her if she could not reckon more,
And plucked away my hands to let her see.
But when she looked back and saw me behind her
She blushed, and asked if it were I did blind her?
And since I sware both by her mask and fan,
To trust no she tongue, that can name a man.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Your great oath hath some exceptions:
But to our former purpose, you is mistress Arthur,
We will attempt another kind of wooing,
And make her hate her husband if we can.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: But not a word of passion or of love.
Have at her now to try her patience,
God save you mistress.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: You are welcome sir.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I pray you where's your husband?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Not within.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Who m. Arthur? him I saw even now
at mistress Mary's the brave courtesans.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Wrong not my husband's reputation so,
I neither can nor will believe you sir.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Poor gentlewoman how much I pity you,
Your husband is become her only guest:
He lodges there, and daily diets there,
He riots, revels, and doth all things,
Nay he is held the m. of misrule,
Amongst a most loathed and abhorred crew:
And can you being a woman suffer this?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Sir, sir, I understand you well enough,
Admit my husband doth frequent that house
Of such dishonest usage, I suppose
He doth it but in zeal to bring them home
By his good counsel, from that course of sin:
And like a christian, seeing them astray
In the broad path that to damnation leads,
He useth thither to direct their feet
Into the narrow way that guides to heaven.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Was ever woman gulled so palpably?
But mistress Arthur think you as you say?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Sir what I think I think, and what I say
I would I could enjoin you to believe.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Faith mistress Arthur I am sorry for you,
And in good sooth, I wish it lay in me
To remedy the least part of these wrongs
Your unkind husband daily proffers you.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: You are deceived he is not unkind,
Although he bear an outward face of hate,
His heart and soul are both assured mine.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Fie mistress Arthur, take a better spirit,
Be not so timorous to rehearse your wrongs,
I say your husband haunts bad company,
Swaggerers, cheaters, wanton courtesans.
There he defiles his body, stains his soul,
Consumes his wealth, undoes himself and you,
In danger of diseases, whose vild names
Are not for any honest mouths to speak,
Nor any chaste ears to receive and hear.
O he will bring that face admired for beauty,
To be more loathed than a leprous skin:
Divorce yourself now whilst the clouds grow black,
Prepare yourself a shelter for the storm,
Abandon his most loathed fellowship:
You are young mistress, will you lose your youth?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Tempt no more devil, thy deformity
Hath changed itself into an angel's shape,
But yet I know thee by thy course of speech:
Thou gets an apple to betray poor Eve,
Whose outside bears a show of pleasant fruit,
But the vild branch on which this apple grew,
Was that which drew poor Eve from paradise.
Thy Siren's song could make me drown myself,
But I am tied unto the mast of truth.
Admit my husband be inclined to vice,
My virtues may in time recall him home,
But if we both should desperate run to sin,
We should abide certain destruction.
But he's like one that over a sweet face
Puts a deformed vizard for his soul,
Is free from any such intents of ill:
Only to try my patience, he puts on
An ugly shape of black intemperance.
Therefore this blot of shame which he now wears,
I with my prayers will purge, wash with tears.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Fuller.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Anselm.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: How likest thou this?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: As schoolboys jerks, apes whips, as lions cocks,
As furies do fasting days, and devil's crosses,
As maids to have their marriage days put off:
I like it as the thing I most do loath,
What wilt thou do? for shame persist no more
In this extremity of frivolous love.
I see my doctrine moves no precise ears,
But such as are professed inamoratos.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O I shall die.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Tush live to laugh a little,
Here's the best subject that thy love affords,
Listen a while and hear this: hoboy speak.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: As in presenti, thou loathest the gift I sent thee,
Nolo plus tarry but die, for the beauteous marry,
Fain would I die by a sword, but what sword shall I die by?
Or by a stone, what stone? nullus lapis iacet ibi.
Knife I have none to sheathe in my breast, or empty my full veins,
Here is no wall or post which I can soil within my bruised brains.
First will I therefore say 2. or 3. Creeds and ave-maries,
And after go buy a poison at the apothecaries.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I prithee Anselm but observe this fellow,
Dost not hear him? he would die for love,
That mishaped love thou wouldst condemn in him,
I see in thee, I prithee note him well.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Were I assured that I were such a lover,
I should be with myself quite out of love:
I prithee let's persuade him still to live.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: That were a dangerous case, perhaps the fellow
In desperation would to soothe us up,
Promise repentant recantation,
And after fall into that desperate course,
Both which I will prevent with policy.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: O death come with thy dart, come death when I bthe
Mors vem veni mors, and from this misery rid me.
She whom I loved, whom I loved, e'en she my sweet pret mar
Doth but flout and mock, and jest, and dissimulary.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I'll fit him finely: in this paper is
The juice of mandrake, by a doctor made
To cast a man whose leg should be cut off,
Into a deep, a cold and senseless sleep,
Of such approved operation,
That who so takes it, is for twice twelve hours
Breathless, and to all men's judgements passed all sense:
This will I give the pedant but in sport,
For when 'tis known to take effect in him,
The world will but esteem it as a jest:
Besides it may be a means to save his life,
For being perfect poison as it seems,
His meaning is, some covetous slave for coin
Will sell it him, though it be held by law
To be no better than flat felony.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Uphold the jest, but he hath spied us, peace.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Gentiles God save you,
Here is a man I have noted oft, most learned in physic,
One man he helped of the cough, another he healed of the tisick:
And I will board him thus: salve o salve magister.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Gratus mihi aduenis quid me cum vis.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Optatum venis paucis to volo.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Si quid industria nostra tibi faciet dic queso.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Attend me sir, I have a simple house,
But as the learned Diogenes saith
In his epistle to Tertullian,
It is extremely troubled with great rats,
I have no muss puss nor grey eyed cat
To hunt them out. O could your learned art
Show me a means how I might poison them:
tutus dum suus, sir Aminadab.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: With all my heart, I am no rat-catcher,
But if you need a poison, here is that
Will pepper both your dogs and rats and cats:
Nay spare your purse, I give this in good will,
And as it proves I pray you send to me,
And let me know, would you ought else with me?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Minime quidem, here's that you say will take them?
A thousand thanks sweet sir, I say to you
As Tully in his Aesop's fables said,
Age tibi gratias, so farewell, vale.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: A diew. Come let us go, I long to see
What the event of this new jest will be.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Good morrow gentlemen, saw you not this way
As you were walking, sir Aminadab?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: M. Arthur as I take it.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Sir the same.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Sir I desire you more familiar love,
Would I could bid myself unto your house,
For I have wished for your acquaintance long.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Sweet m. Anselm I desire yours too:
Will you come dine with me at home to morrow,
You shall be welcome I assure you sir.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I fear sir I shall prove too bold a guest.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: You shall be welcome if you bring your friend.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: O lord sir, we shall be too troublesome.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Nay now I will enforce a promise from you,
Shall I expect you?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Yes with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: A thousand thanks. Yonder's the schoolmaster.
So till tomorrow twenty times farewell.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I double all your farewells twenty fold.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O this acquaintance was well scraped of me,
by this my love tomorrow I shall see.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: This poison shall by force expel,
Amorem love, infernum hell.
Per hoc venenum ego I,
For my sweet lovely lass will die.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: What do I hear of poison, which sweet means
Must make me a brave frolic widower?
It seems the doting fool being forlorn
Hath got some compound mixture, in despair
To end his desperate fortunes and his life:
I'll get it from him, and with this make way
To my wife's night, and to my love's fair day.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: In nomine dominae, friends farewell:
I know death comes here's such a smell.
Pater et mater, father and mother,
Frater et soror, sister and brother,
And my sweet Mary, not these drugs,
Do send me to the infernal bugs,
But thy unkindness, so adieu,
Hobgoblins now I come to you.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Hold man I say, what will the mad mad do?
I have I got thee, thou shalt go with me:
No more of that, fie sir Minadab
Destroy yourself: if I but hear hereafter
You practise such revenge upon yourself,
All your friends shall know that for a wench,
A paltry wench, you would have killed yourself.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: O tace queso, do not name
This frantic deed of mine for shame:
My sweet magister not a word,
I'll neither drown me in a ford
Nor give my neck such a scope,
To embrace it with a hempen rope;
I'll die no way till nature will me,
and death come with his dart and kill me.
If what is passed you will conceal,
And nothing to the world reveal,
Nay as Quintilian said of yore,
I'll strive to kill myself no more.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: On that condition I'll conceal this deed,
To morrow pray come and dine with me:
For I have many strangers, amongst the rest,
Some are desirous of your company.
You will not fail me?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: No in sooth, I'll try the sharpness of my tooth,
In steed of poison, I will eat
Rabbits, capons, and such meat:
And so as Pythagoras says,
With wholesome fare prolong my days.
But sir will mistress Mall be there?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: She shall, she shall man never fear.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Then my spirit becomes stronger,
And I will live and stretch longer:
For Ovid said, and did not lie,
That poisoned men do often die.
But poison henceforth I'll not eat,
Whilst I can other victuals get:
To morrow if you make a feast,
Be sure sir I will be your guest.
But keep my counsel, vale tu,
And till to morrow sir adieu:
At your table I will prove
If I can eat away my love.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: O I am glad I have thee, now devise
A way how to bestow it cunningly:
It shall be thus: to morrow I'll pretend
A reconcilement twixt my wife and me,
And to that end I will invite thus many:
first justice reason, as the chief man there.
My father Arthur, old Lusam, young Lusam, m. Fuller,
And m. Anselm I have bid already.
Then will I have my lovely Mary too,
Be it but to spite my wife before she die:
For die she shall before tomorrow night.
The operation of this poison is
Not suddenly to kill, they that take it
Fall in a sleep, and then 'tis passed recure,
And this will I put in her cup tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: This 'tis to have such a master, I have sought him at the change, at the school, at every place, but I cannot find him nowhere . O cry mercy, my mistress would entreat you to come home.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: I cannot come tonight , some urgent business
Will all this night employ me otherwise.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I believe my mistress would con you as much thank to do that business at home as abroad.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Here take my purse, and bid my wife provide
Good cheer against tomorrow, there will be
Two or three strangers of my late acquaintance.
Sirrah go you to justice reason's house,
Invite him first with all solemnity.
Go to my fathers, and my father in laws,
Here take this note.
The rest that come I will invite myself,
About it with what quick dispatch thou canst.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I warrant you master I'll dispatch this business with more honesty, than you'll dispatch yours. But master will the gentlewoman be there?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: What gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p:
The gentlewoman of the old house, that is as well known by the colour she lays of her cheese, as an alehouse
by the painting is laid of his lettuce: she that is like homo, common to all men: she that is beholding to no trade, but lives of herself.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Sirrah be gone, or I will send you hence.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I'll go, but by this hand I'll tell my mistress as soon as I come home, that mistress Lightheels comes to dinner tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Sweet mistress Mary I'll invite myself:
And there I'll frolic, sup, and spend the night.
My plot is currant, here 'tis in my hand
Will make me happy in my second choice,
And I may freely challenge as mine own,
What I am how enforced to seek by stealth.
Love is not much unlike ambition,
For in them both all lets must be removed
Twixt every crown and him that would aspire,
And he that will attempt to win the same,
Must plunge up to the depth o'er head and ears,
And hazard drowning in that purple sea.
So he that loves, must needs through blood and fire,
And do all things to compass his desire.

div.stage: Enter mistress Arthur and her maid.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Come spread the table: is the hall well rubbed,
The cushions in the windows neatly laid,
The cupboard of plate set out, the casements stuck
With rosemary and flowers, the carpets brushed?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I forsooth mistress.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Look to the kitchen maid, and bid the cook take down the oven stone, the pies be burned: here take my keys and give him out more spice.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Yes forsooth mistress.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Where's that knave Pipkin, bid him spread the cloth,
Fetch the clean diaper napkins from my chest,
Set out the guilded salt, and bid the fellow
make himself handsome, get him a clean band.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Indeed forsooth mistress he is such a sloven
That nothing will sit handsome about him,
He had a pound of soap to scour his face,
And yet his brow looks like the chimney stock.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: He'll be a sloven still: maid take this apron,
And bring me one of linen, quickly maid.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: I go forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: There was a curtsy, let me see't again.
I that was well. I fear my guests will come
Ere we be ready, what a spite is this.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.l: Mistress I pray take pipkin from the fire,
We cannot keep his fingers from the roast.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Bid him come hither, what a knave is that.
Fie, fie, never out of the kitchen,
Still broiling by the fire.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: I hope you will not take Pipkin from the fire
Till the broth be enough.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Well sirrah get a napkin and a trencher
And wait today. So let me see my apron.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Mistress I can tell ye one thing, my m. wench
Will come home today to dinner.

div.stage: Enter justice reason and his man.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: She shall be welcome if she be his guest.
But here's some of our guests are come already,
A chair for justice reason sirrah.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Good morrow mistress Arthur, you are like a good housewife,
At your request I am come home, what a chair!
Thus age seeks ease: where is your husband mistress?
What a cushion too!

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: I pray you ease your tail sir.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Marry and will good fellow, twenty thanks.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: M. hue as welcome as heart can tell, or tongue can think.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I thank you m. Pipkin, I have got many a good dish of broth by your means.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: According to the ancient courtesy you are welcome: according to the time and place, you are heartily welcome: when they are busied at the board, we will find ourselves busied in the buttery: and so sweet Hugh according to our scholar's phrase, gratulor aduentum tuum.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: I will answer you with the like sweet pipkin, gratias.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: As much grace as you will, but as little of it as you can good Hugh. But here comes more guests.

div.stage: Enter old Arthur, and old Lusam.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: More stools and cushions for these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: What m. justice reason, are you here?
Who would have thought to have met you in this place?

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: What say mine eyes, is justice reason here?
Mountain's may meet, and so I see may we.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Well when men meet they meet,
And when they part, they oft leave one another's company:
So we being met, are met.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Truly you say true:
And m. justice reason speaks but reason.
To hear how wisely men of law will speak.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Good morrow gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: What are you there?

sp.speaker: A●
sp.l: Good morrow mistress, and good morrow all.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: If I may be so bold in a strange place,
I say good morrow, and as much to you.
I pray gentlemen will you sit down?
We have been young like you, and if you live
Unto our age, you will be old like us.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Be ruled by reason, but who's here?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Salvete omnes, and good day
To all at once, as I may say,
First master justice, next old Arthur,
That gives me pension by the quarter:
To my good mistress, and the rest,
That are the founders of this feast.
In brief I speak to omnes all,
That to their meat intend to fall.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Welcome sir Aminadab, o my son
Hath profited exceeding well with you,
Sit down, sit down, by mistress Arthur's leave.

div.stage: Enter young Arthur, young Lusam, and mistress Mary.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Gentlemen, welcome all, whilst I deliver
Their private welcomes, wife be it your charge,
To give this gentlewoman entertainment.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Husband, I will: o this is she usurps
The precious interest of my husband's love:
Though as I am a woman, I could well
Thrust such a lewd companion out of doors,
Yet as I am a true obedient wife,
I'd kiss her feet to do my husbands will.
You are entirely welcome gentlewoman,
Indeed you are, pray do not doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I thank you mistress Arthur, now by my little honesty,
It much repents me to wrong so chaste a woman.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Gentles, put o'er your legs, first m. justice,
Here you shall sit.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: And here shall mistress Arthur sit by me.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Pardon me sir, she shall have my wife's place.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Indeed you shall, for he will have it so.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.p: If you will needs, but I shall do you wrong to take your place.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I by my faith you should.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.p: That is no wrong which we impute no wrong, I pray you sit.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Gentlemen all, I pray you seat yourselves:
What sir Aminadab, I know where your heart is.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Mum not a word, pax vobis, peace:
Come gentiles I'll be of this mess.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: So, who gives thanks?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Sir that will I.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I pray you too it by and by, where's Pipkin,
Wait at the board, let m. reason's man
Be had into the buttery, but first give him
A napkin and a trencher. Well said Hugh,
Wait at your master's elbow, now say grace.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Gloria deo, sirs proface,
Attend me now whilst I say grace.
For bread and salt, for grapes and malt,
For flesh and fish, and every dish:
Mutton and beef, of all meats chief:
For cow-heels, chitterlings, tripes and souse,
And other meat that's in the house:
For racks, for breasts, for legs, for loins,
For pies with raisins, and with prunes:
For fritters, pancakes, and for frays,
For venison pasties and minced pies:
Sheepshead and garlic, brawn and mustard,
Wafers, spiced cakes, tart and custard,
For capons, rabbits, pigs and geese,
For apples, caraways and cheese:
For all these and many more,
Benidicanus domino.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Amen.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I con you thanks, but sir Aminadab,
Is that your scholar? now I promise you
he is a towards stripling of his age.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Who I forsooth, yes indeed forsooth I am his scholar, I would you should well think I have profited under him too, you shall hear if he will pose me.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I pray you let's hear him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Huc ades Pipkin.
Adsum.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Quot casus sunt, how many cases are there?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Marry a great many:

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Well answered a great many, there are six,
Six a great many, 'tis well answered,
And which be they?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: A bow-case, a capcase, a comb-case, a lute-case, a fiddle-case, and a candle-case.

sp.speaker: Iust:
sp.l: I know them all, again well answered:
Pray God my youngest boy profit no worse.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: How many parsons are there?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: I'll tell you as many as I know, if you'll give me leave to reckon them.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: I prithee do.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: The parson of Fanchurch, the parson of Pancridge, and the parson of.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Well sir about your business: now will I
