Temper the cup my loathed wife shall drink:

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Daughter methinks you are exceeding sad:

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Faith daughter so thou art exceeding sad:

sp.speaker: Miss: Ar:
sp.l: 'Tis but my countenance, for my heart is merry,
Mistress were you as merry as you are welcome,
You should not sit so sadly as you do.

sp.speaker: Ma:
sp.l: 'Tis but because I am seated in your place,
Which is frequented seldom with true mirth.

sp.speaker: Miss: Ar.
sp.l: The fault is neither in the place nor me.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: How say you lady to him you last did lie by?
All this is no more prebibo tibi.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I thank you sir, mistress this draught shall be
To him that loves both you and me.

sp.speaker: Mistress Ar.
sp.l: I know your meaning.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Now to me;
If she have either love or charity.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Hear m. justice, this to your grave years,
A mournful draught God wot, half wine, half tears.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Let come my wench, here youngsters, to you all,
You are silent, here's that will make you talk.
Wenches, methink you sit like Puritants,
Never a jest abroad to make them laugh?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Sir, since you move speech of a Puritan,
If you will give me audience I will tell ye
As good a jest as ever you did hear.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: A jest, that's excellent.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Before hand let's prepare ourselves to laugh,
A jest is nothing if it be not graced:
Now, now, I pray you when begins this jest?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I came unto a Puritan to woo her,
And roughly did salute her with a kiss:
Away quoth she, and rudely pushed me from her,
Brother, by yea and nay I like not this,
And still with amorous talk she was saluted,
My artless speech with scripture was confuted.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Good, good indeed, the best that ere I heard.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I promise you it was exceeding good.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Oft I frequented her abroad by night,
And courted her, and spoke her wondrous fair,
But ever somewhat did offend her sight,
Either my double ruff, or my long hair:
My scarf was vain, my garments hung too low,
My Spanish shoe was cut too broad at toe.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, the best that ever I heard.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I parted for that time, and came again,
seeming to be conformed in look and speech,
My shoes were sharp toed, and my band was plain,
Close to my thigh my metamorphized breech:
My cloak was narrow caped, my hair cut shorter,
Off went my scarf, thus marched I to the porter.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ha, ha, was ever heard the like?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: The porter spying me, did lead me in,
Where his fair mistress sat reading on a chapter:
Peace to this house quoth I, and those within,
Which holy speech with admiration wrapped her,
And ever as I spoke, and came her nigh,
Seeming divine, turned up the white of eye.

sp.speaker: Inst.
sp.l: So, so, what then, what then?

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Forward, I pray forward sir.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I spoke divinely, and I called her sister,
And by this means we were acquainted well:
By yea and nay, I will quoth I and kissed her,
She blushed and said that long tongued men would tell,
I seemed to be as secret as the night,
And said, on sooth I would put out the light.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: In sooth he would, a passing passing jest.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: O do not swear quoth she, yet put it out,
Because I would not have you break your oath.
I felt a bed there as I groped about,
In troth quoth I, here will we rest us both.
Swear you in troth quoth she, had you not sworn
I had not don't, but took it in foul scorn,
Than you will come quoth I; though I be loath,
I'll come quoth she, be it but to keep your oath.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: 'Tis very pretty, but now whence the jest?

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: O forward to the jest in any case.

sp.speaker: Old Lu
sp.l: I would not for angel lose the jest.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Here's right the dunghill cock that finds a pearl,
To talk of wit to these, is as a man
should cast out jewels to a herd of swine,
Why in the last words did consist the jest.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: Ay, in the last words? ha, ha, ha,
It was an excellent admired jest,
To them that understood it.

div.stage: Enter young Arthur, with a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: It was indeed, I must for fashion's sake
Say as they say, but otherwise, o God.
Good m. Arthur thanks for our good cheer.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Gentlemen, welcome all, now hear me speak;
One special cause that moved me lead you hither,
Is for ancient grudge that hath long since
Continued twixt my modest wife and me,
The wrongs that I have done her, I recant.
In either hand I hold a several cup,
This in the right hand, wife I drink to thee,
This in the left hand pledge me in this draught,
Burying all former hatred, so have to thee.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: The welcomest pledge that yet I ever took:
Were this wine poison, or did taste like gall,
The honey sweet condition of your draught,
Would make it drink like nectar, I will pledge you,
Were it the last that I should ever drink.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Make that account; thus gentlemen you see,
Our late discord brought to a unity.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Ecce quam bonum et quam iucundum,
Est habitare featres in unum.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: My heart doth taste the sweetness of your pledge,
And I am glad to see this sweet accord.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: Glad quotha, there's not one amongst us,
But may be exceeding glad.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I am, I marry am I, that I am.

sp.speaker: Yon. lus
sp.l: The best accord that could betide their loves.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: The worst accord that could betide my love.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: What rising gentles, keep your places,
I'll close up your stomachs with a grace.
O dominae et chare puter,
That givest us wine in stead of water,
And from the pond and river clear,
Makest nappy ale and good march beer,
That sendest us sundry sorts of meat,
And every thing we drink or eat,
To maids, to wives, to boys, to men,
Laus deo sancte amen.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: So much good do ye all, and gentlemen,
Accept your welcomes better than your cheer.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: Nay so we do, I'll give you thanks for all.
Come m. justice, you do walk our way,
And m. Arthur, and old Hugh your man,
We'll be the first will strain courtesy.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: God be with you all.

div.stage: Exeunt old Arthur, Lusam, and justice.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Propimus ego sum, I'll be the next,
And man you home, how say you lady?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: I pray you do, good sir Aminadab.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: Sir, if it be not too much trouble to you,
Let me entreat that kindness at your hands.

sp.speaker: Amina.
sp.l: Entreat; fie, no sweet lass command.
Sic so nunc, now take the upper hand.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Come wife, this meeting was all for our sakes,
I long to see the force my poison takes.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: My dear, dear husband, in exchange of hate,
My love and heart shall on your service wait.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: So doth my love on thee, but long no more,
To her rich love, thy service is too poor.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: For shame no more, you had best expostulate
Your love with every stranger, leave these sighs,
And change them to familiar conference.

sp.speaker: Yon. lus
sp.l: Trust me the virtues of young Arthur's wife,
Her constancy, modest humility,
Her patience, and admired temperance,
Have made me love all women kind the better.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: O my mistress, my mistress, she's dead, she's gone, she's dead, she's gone.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What's that he says?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Out of my way, stand back I say, all joy from earth is fled,
She is this day as cold as clay, my mistress she is dead:
Oh lord, my mistress, my mistress.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: What mistress Arthur dead? my soul is vanished,
And the world's wonder from the world quite banished:
Oh I am sick, my pain grows worse and worse,
I am quite struck thorough with this late discourse.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: What faints thou man? I'll lead thee hence for shame,
Sound at the tidings of a woman's death?
Intolerable, and beyond all thought,
Come my love's fool, give me thy hand to lead,
This day one body and two hearts are dead.

sp.speaker: Young lus
sp.l: But now she was as well as well might be,
And on the sudden dead; joy in excess
Hath overrun her poor disturbed soul.
I'll after and see how master Arthur takes it.
His former hate far more suspicious makes it.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.p: My m. hath left his gloves behind where he sat in his chair, and hath sent me to fetch them, it is such an old snudge, he will not lose the dropping of his nose.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p:
O mistress, o Hugh, o Hugh, o mistress, Hugh I must
needs beat thee, I am mad, I am lunatic, I must fall upon thee, my mistress is dead.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.p: O m. Pipkin, what do you mean, what do you mean m. Pipkin?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: O hue, o mistress, o mistress, o hue.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.l: O Pipkin, o God, o God, o Pipkin.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: O hue, I am mad, bear with me, I cannot choose, o death, o mistress, o mistress, o death.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.p: Death quotha, he hath almost made me dead with beating.

div.stage: Enter reason, old Arthur, and old Lusam.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I wonder why the knave my man stays thus,
And comes not back, see where the villain loiters.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: O m. justice, m. Arthur, m. Lusam, wonder not why I thus blow and bluster, my mistress is dead, dead is my mistress, and therefore hang yourselves, on my mistress, my mistress.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: My son's wife dead?

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: My daughter.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Mistress Arthur, here comes her husband.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: O here the woefulst husband comes alive,
No husband now, the wight that did uphold
That name of husband is now quite o'erthrown,
And I am left a hapless widower.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Fain would I speak, if grief would suffer me.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: As master Arthur says, so say I,
If grief would let me, I would weeping die,
To be thus hapless in my aged years,
Oh I would speak, but my words melt to tears.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Go in, go in, and view the sweetest course
That ere was laid upon a mournful room,
You cannot speak for weeping sorrows doom.
Bad news are rife, good tidings seldom come.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What frantic humour doth thus haunt my sense,
Striving to breed destruction in my spirit?
When I would sleep, the ghost of my sweet love,
Appears unto me in an angel's shape,
When I am wake, my fantasy presents
As in a glass, the shadow of my love:
When I would speak, her name intrudes itself
Into the perfect echoes of my speech.
And though my thought beget some other word,
Yet will my tongue speak nothing but her name:
If I do meditate it is on her,
If dream on her, or if discourse on her,
I think her ghost doth haunt me, as in times
Of former darkness old wives tales report,
Here comes my bitter genius, whose advice
Directs me still in all my actions.
How now, from whence come you?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Faith from the street, in which as I passed by,
I met the modest mistress Arthur's course:
And after her as mourners, first her husband,
Next justice reason, then old m. Arthur,
Old m. Lusam, and young Lusam too,
With many other kinsfolks, neighbours, friends,
And others that lament her funeral,
Her body is by this laid in the vault.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: And in that vault my body I will lay,
I prithee leave me, thither is my way.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I am sure you jest, you mean not as you say.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: No, no, I'll but go to the church and prey.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Nay then we shall be troubled with your humour.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: As ever thou didst love me, or as ever
thou didst delight in my society,
By all the rights of friendship, and of love,
Let me entreat thy absence but one hour,
And at the hour's end I will come to thee.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Nay if you will be foolish, and past reason,
I'll wash my hands like Pilate, from thy folly,
And suffer thee in these extremities.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Now it is night, and the bright lamps of heaven
Are half burned out, now bright Adelbora
Welcomes the cheerful daystar to the fast,
And harmless stillness hath possessed the world.
This is the church, this hollow is the vault,
Where the dead body of my saint remains,
And this the coffin that enshrines her body,
For her bright soul is now in paradise.
My coming is with no intent of sin,
Or to defile the body of the dead,
But rather take my last farewell of her,
Or languishing and dying by her side.
My airy soul post after hers to heaven,
First with this latest kiss I seal my love.
Her lips are warm, and I am much deceived
If that she stir not: and this Golgotha,
This place of dead men's bones is terrible,
Presenting fearful apparitions.
It is some spirit that in the coffin lies,
And makes my hair start up an end with fear,
Come to thyself faint heart, she sits upright,
Oh I would hide me, but I know not where;
Tush if it be a spirit, 'tis a good spirit,
For with her body living, ill she knew not,
And with her body dead, ill cannot meddle.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Who am I? or where am I?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O she speaks, and by her language now I know she lives.

sp.speaker: Mi Ar.
sp.l: O who can tell me where I am become?
For in this darkness I have lost myself,
I am not dead, for I have sense and life,
How come I then in this coffin buried?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Anselm be bold she lives, and destiny
Hath trained thee hither to redeem her life.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Lives any amongst these dead? none but myself.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O yes, a man whose heart till now was dead,
Lives and survives at your return to life:
Nay start not, I am Anselm, one who long
Hath doted on your fair perfection,
And loving you more than became me well,
Was hither sent by some strange providence,
To bring you from these hollow vaults below,
To be a liver in the world again.

sp.speaker: Miss Ar.
sp.l: I understand you, and I thank the heavens,
That sent you to revive me from this fear,
And I embrace my safety with good will.

div.stage: Enter Aminadab with two or three boys.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Mane citus lectum fuge mollem discute somnum,
Templa pet as supplex et venerarum deum.
Shake off thy sleep, get up betimes, go to the church and prey,
And never fear, God will thee hear, and keep thee all the day.
Good counsel boys, observe it, mark it well,
This early rising, this diliculo,
Is good both for your bodies and your minds.
'Tis not yet day, give me my tinderbox,
Mean time unloose your satchels and your books,
Draw, draw, and take you to your lessons boys.

sp.speaker: I. boy.
sp.l: O lord m. what's that in the white sheet?

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: In the white sheet my boy, dic ubi, where?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Vide master, vide illic there.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: O dominae, dominae, keep us from evil,
A charm from flesh, the world, and the devil.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: O tell me not my husband was ingrate,
Or that he did attempt to poison me,
Or that he laid me here, and I was dead,
These are no means at all to win my love.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Sweet mistress, he bequath you to the earth,
You promised him to be his wife till death,
And you have kept your promise, but now since
The world, your husband, and your friends suppose
That you are dead, grant me but one request,
And I will swear never to solicit more,
Your sacred thoughts to my dishonest love.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: So your demand may be no prejudice
To my chaste name, no wrong unto my husband,
No suit that may concern my wedlock breach,
I yield unto it, but to pass the bands of modesty and chastity,
First will I be myself again
Unto this grave, and never part from hence,
Then taint my soul with black impurity.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Take here my hand and faithful heart to gauge,
That I will never tempt you more to sin:
This my request is, since your husband dotes
Upon a lewd lascivious courtesan,
Since he hath broke the bands of your chaste bed,
And like a murderer sent you to your grave,
Do but go with me to my mother's house,
There shall you live in secret for a space,
Only to see the end of such lewd lust,
And know the difference of a chaste wife's bed,
And one whose life is in all looseness led.

sp.speaker: Miss Ar.
sp.l: Your mother is a virtuous matron held,
Her counsel, conference, and company,
May much avail me, there a space I'll stay,
Upon condition as you said before,
You never will move your unchaste suit more.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: My faith is pawned, o never had chaste wife,
A husband of so lewd and unchaste life.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Mistress I long have served you, even since
These bristled hairs upon my grave like chin
Were all unborn: when I first came to you
These infant feathers of these ravens wings,
Were not once begun.

sp.speaker: Spl.
sp.l: No indeed they were not.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Now in my two moustaches for a need,
Wanting a rope, I well could hang myself:
I prithee mistress, for all my long service,
For all the love that I have born thee long,
Do me this favour now to marry me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Marry come up you blockhead, you great ass,
What wouldst thou have me marry with a devil,
But peace, no more, here comes the silly fool
That we so long have set our lime-twigs for,
Be gone, and leave me to entangle him.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: What mistress marry!

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: O good master Arthur, where have you been this week, this month, this year?
This year said I? where have you been this age?
Unto a lover every minute seems time out of mind.
How should I think you love me,
That can endure to stay so long from me?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: In faith sweet heart I saw thee yesternight.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I true, you did, but since you saw me not,
At twelve o'clock you parted from my house,
and now 'tis morning, and new strucken seven.
Seven hours thou staidst from me, why didst thou so?
They are my seven years prenticeship of woe.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I prithee be patient, I had some occasion
That did enforce me from thee yesternight.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I you are soon enforced, fool that I am,
To dote on one that naught respecteth me:
'Tis but my fortune, I am born to bear it,
And every one shall have their destiny.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Nay weep not wench, thou woundst me with thy tears.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I am a fool, and so you make me too,
These tears were better kept, then spent in waste,
On one that neither tenders them nor me:
What remedy, but if I chance to die,
Or to miscarry with that I go withal,
I'll take my death that thou art cause thereof.
You told me, that when your wife was dead,
You would forsake all others, and take me.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I told thee so, and I will keep my word,
And for that end I came thus early to thee:
I have procured a licence, and this night:
We will be married in a lawless church.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: These news revive me, and do somewhat ease
The thought that was new gotten to my heart.
But shall it be tonight ?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I wench, tonight .
A sennet and odd days since my wife died
Is passed already, and her timeless death,
Is but a nine days' talk, come go with me,
And it shall be dispatched presently.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Nay then I see thou lovest me, and I find
By this last motion, thou art grown more kind.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: My love and kindness like my age shall grow,
and with the time increase, and thou shalt see,
The older I grow, the kinder I will be.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I so I hope it will but as for mine,
That with my age shall day by day decline.
Come shall we go?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: With thee to the world's end.
Whose beauty most admire, and all commend.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: 'Tis true as I relate the circumstance,
And she is with my mother safe at home,
But yet for all the hate I can allege
Against her husband, nor for all the love
That on my own part I can urge her too,
Will she be won to gratify my love.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: All things are full of ambiguity,
And I admire this wondrous accident.
But Anselm, Arthur's about a new wife, a bona raba,
How will she take it when she hears this news?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I think even as a virtuous matron should;
It may be that report may from thy mouth
Beget some pity from her flinty heart,
And I will urge her with it presently.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Unless report be false, they are linked already,
They are fast as words can tie them: I will tell thee
How I by chance did meet him the last night.
One said to me, this Arthur did intend
To have a wife, and presently to marry:
Amid the street I met him as my friend,
And to his love a present he did carry.
It was some ring, some stomacher, or toy,
I spoke to him, and bad God glue him joy.
God give me joy quoth he, of what I pray?
Marry quoth I, your wedding that is towards.
'tis false quoth he, and would have gone his way.
Come, come, quoth I, so near it, and so froward:
I urged him hard by our familiar loves,
Prayed him withal not to forget my gloves.
Then he began, your kindness hath been great,
Your courtesy great, and your love not common,
Yet so much favour pray let me entreat,
To be excused from marrying any woman.
I knew the wench that is become his bride,
And smiled to think how deeply he had lied,
For first he swore he did not court a maid,
A wife he could not, she was elsewhere tied,
And as for such as widows were, he said,
And deeply swore, none such should be his bride,
Widow, nor wife, nor maid, I asked no more,
Knowing he was betrothed unto a whore.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Is it not mistress mary that you mean,
She that did dine with us at Arthur's house?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: The same, the same, here comes the gentle woman,
O mistress Arthur, I am of your counsel,
Welcome from death to life.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Mistress, this gentleman hath news to tell ye,
And as you like of it, so think of me.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Your husband hath already got a wife,
A huffing wench i'faith, whose ruffling silks,
Make with their motion, music unto love,
And you are quite forgotten.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: I have sworn to move this my unchaste demand no more.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: When doth your colour change?
When doth your eyes sparkle with fire to revenge these wrongs?
When doth your tongue break into rage and wrath
against that scum of manhood, your vile husband,
He first misused you.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: And yet can you love him?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: He left your chaste bed, to defile the bed
Of sacred marriage with a courtesan.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Yet can you love him?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: And not content with this,
Abused your honest name with slanderous words,
And filled your hushed house with unquietness.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: And can you love him yet?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Nay did he not with his rude fingers dash you on the face,
And double dye your coral lips with blood?
Hath he not torn those gold wires from your head,
Wherewith Apollo would have strung his harp,
And kept them to play music to the gods?
Hath he not beat you, and with his rude fists,
Upon that crimson temperature of your cheeks,
Laid a lead colour with his boisterous blows.

sp.speaker: Ansel.
sp.l: And can you love him yet?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Then did he not
Either by poison, or some other plot,
Send you to death, where by his providence,
God hath preserved you by wondrous miracle?
Nay after death hath he not scandalised
Your place, with an immodest courtesan?

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: And can you love him yet?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: And yet, and yet, and still, and ever whilst I breathe this air:
Nay after death my unsubstantial soul,
Like a good angel shall attend on him,
And keep him from all harm.
But is he married, much good do his heart,
Pray God she may content him better far
than I have done: long may they live in peace,
Till I disturb their solace; but because
I fear some mischief doth hang his head,
I'll weep mine eyes dry with my present care,
And for their healths make hoarse my tongue with prayer.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Art sure she is a woman? if she be,
She is created of nature's purity.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: O yes, I too well know she is a woman,
Henceforth my virtue shall my love withstand,
And on my striuing thoughts get the upper hand.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Then thus resolved, I straight will drink to thee,
A health thus deep, to drown thy melancholy.

div.stage: Enter Marry, young Arthur, Brabo, and Splay.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Not have my will, yes I will have my will,
Shall I not go abroad but when you please?
Can I not now and then meet with my friends,
But at my coming home you will control me?
Marry come up.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Where are thou patience?
Nay rather where's become my former spleen?
I had a wife would not have used me so.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why you Jack sauce, you cuckold, you what not,
What am not I of age sufficient
To go and come still when my pleasure serves,
But must I have you sir to question me?
Not have my will? yes I will have my will.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I had a wife would not have used me so,
But she is dead.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Not have her will, sir she shall have her will,
She says she will, and sir I say she shall.
Not have her will? that were a jest indeed.
Who says she shall not, if I be disposed
to man her forth, who shall find fault with it?
What's he that dare say black's her eye?
Though you be married sir, yet you must know
That she was ever born to have her will.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: Not have her will, god's passion I say still,
A woman's nobody that wants her will.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Where is my spirit, what shall I maintain
A strumpet with a Brabo and her bawd,
To beard me out of my authority.
What am I from a master made a slave?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A slave? nay worse, dost thou maintain my man,
And this my maid? 'tis I maintain them both.
I am thy wife, I will not be dressed so
While thy gold lasts, but then most willingly
I will bequeath thee to flat beggary.
I do already hate thee, do thy worst,
Nay touch me if thou dar'st: what shall he beat me?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: I'll make him seek his fingers amongst the dogs,
That dares to touch my mistress: never fear,
My sword shall smooth the wrinkles of his brows
That bends a frown upon my mistress.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I had a wife would not have used me so,
But God is just.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now Arthur, if I knew
What in this world would most torment thy soul,
That I would do: would all my evil usage
Could make thee straight despair, and hang thyself.
Now I remember, where is Arthur's man
Pipkin, that slave? go turn him out of doors,
None that loves Arthur, shall have houseroom here.
Yonder he comes, Brabo discard the fellow.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Shall I be overmastered in my own?
Be thyself Arthur, strumpet he shall stay.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: What shall he Brabo, shall he mistress splay?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Shall he? he shall not: breathes there any living,
Dares say he shall, when Brabo says he shall not?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Is there no law for this? she is my wife,
Should I complain, I should be rather mocked:
I am content, keep by thee whom thou list.
Discharge whom thou thinkst good, do what thou wilt,
Rise, go to bed, stay at home, or go abroad
At thy good pleasure keep all companies:
So that for all this, I may have but peace.
Be unto me as I was to my wife,
Only give me what I denied her then,
A little love, and some small quietness.
If he displease thee, turn him out of doors.

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p: Who me? turn me out of doors? is this all the wages I shall have at the year's end, to be turned out of doors? you mistress, you are a.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.p: A what? speak, a what? touch her, and touch me; taint her, and taint me, speak, speak, a what?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Marry a woman that is kin to the frost.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: How do you mean that?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: And you are a kin to the Latin word, to understand.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: And what's that?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.l: Subaudi, subaudi: and sir, do you not use to pink doublets?

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Pip.
sp.p:
I took you for a cutter, you are of a great kindred; you are a common cozener, everybody calls you cousin: besides, they say you are a very good warrener, you have been an old coney catcher: but if I be turned a-begging , as I know not what I am born too, and that you ever come to the said trade, as nothing is unpossible, I'll set all the commonwealth of beggars on your back, and all the congregation of vermin shall be put to your keeping, and then if you be not more bitten than all the
company of beggars besides, I'll not have my will: zounds turned out of doors, I'll go and set up my trade, a dish to drink in that I have within, a wallet that I'll make of an old shirt, than my speech for the lord's sake, I beseech your worship, than I must have a lame leg, I'll go to football and break my shins, and I am provided for that.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What stands the villain prating, hence you slave.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Art thou yet pleased?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: When I have had my humour.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Good friends for manners sake a while withdraw.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: It is our pleasure sir to stand aside.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Marry what cause hast thou to use me thus?
From nothing I have raised thee to much wealth,
'Twas more than I did owe thee: many a pound,
Nay many a hundred pound I spent on thee
In my wife's time, and once but by my means
Thou hadst been in much danger, but in all things
My purse and credit ever bore thee out:
I did not owe thee this, I had a wife
That would have laid herself beneath my feet
To do me service, her I set at naught
For the entire affection I bore thee.
To show that I have loved thee, have I not
Above all women made chief choice of thee?
An argument sufficient of my love,
What reason then hast thou to wrong me thus?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: It is my humour.

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: O but such humours honest wives should purge:
He show thee a far greater instance yet
Of the true love that I have born to thee,
Thou knewest my brother's wife, was she not fair?

sp.speaker: ●●●y.
sp.l: So so.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: But more than fair, was she not virtuous
Endued with the beauty of the mind?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Faith so they said.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Hark in thine ear, I'll trust thee with my life,
Than which what greater instance of my love:
Thou knewest full well how suddenly she died,
To enjoy thy love even then I poisoned her.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: How poisoned her! accursed murderer,
I'll ring this fatal alarm in all ears,
Than which what greater instance of my hate.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Wilt thou not keep my counsel?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Villain no, thou'lt poison me as thou hast poisoned her.

sp.speaker: Yong. Ar.
sp.l: Dost thou reward me thus for all my love?
Then Arthur fly and seek to save thy life,
Oh difference twixt a chaste and unchaste wife.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Pursue the murderer, apprehend him straight.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why what's the matter mistress?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: This villain Arthur poisoned his first wife,
Which he in secret hath confessed to me:
Go and fetch warrants from the justices
To attach the murderer, he once hanged and dead,
His wealth is mine: pursue the slave that's dead.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Mistress I will, he shall not pass this land
But I will bring him bound with this strong hand.

sp.speaker: Miss: Ar.
sp.l: O what are the vain pleasures of the world,
That in their actions we affect them so?
Had I been born a servant, my low life
Had steady stood from all these miseries:
The waving reeds stand free from every gust,
When the tall oaks are rent up by the roots:
What is vain beauty but an idle breath?
Why are we proud of that which so soon changes?
But rather wish the beauty of the mind,
Which neither time can alter, sickness change,
Violence deface, nor the black hand of envy,
Smudge and disgrace, or spoil, or make deformed.
O had my riotous husband born this mind,
He had been happy, I had been more blessed,
And peace had prought our quiet souls to rest.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: O whither shall I fly to save my life,
When murder and despair dogs at my heels?
O misery, thou never foundst a friend,
All friends forsake men in adversity:
My brother hath denied to succour me,
Upbraiding me with name of murderer.
My uncle's double bar their doors against me;
My father hath denied to shelter me,
And cursed me worse than Adam did vile Eve.
I that within these two days had more friends
Than I could number with arithmetic,
Have now no more than one poor cipher is,
And that poor cipher I supply myself.
All that I durst commit my fortunes too,
I have tried, and find none to relieve my wants,
My sudden flight, and fear of future shame,
Left me unfurnished of all necessaries,
And these three days I have not tasted food.

sp.speaker: Miss: Ar:
sp.l: It is my husband, o how just is heaven!
Poorly disguised, and almost hunger-starved.
How comes this change?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Doth no man follow me?
O how suspicious guilty murder is,
I starve for hunger, and I die for thirst:
Had I a kingdom I would sell my crown
For a small bit of bread: I shame to beg,
and yet perforce I must or beg or starve.
This house belike longs to some gentlewoman,
And here's a woman, I will beg of her:
Good mistress look upon a poor man's wants.
Whom do I see? tush Arthur she is dead:
But that I saw her dead and buried,
I would have sworn it had been Arthur's wife:
But I will leave her, shame forbids me beg
On one so much resembles her.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Come hither fellow, wherefore dost thou turn
Thy guilty looks and blushing face aside?
It seems thou hast not been brought up to this.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: You say true mistress: then for charity,
And for her sake whom you resemble most,
Pity my present want and misery.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: It seems thou hast been in some better plight,
Sit down I prithee, men though they be poor,
Should not be scorned: to ease thy hunger, first
Eat these conserves: and now I prithee tell me,
What thou hast been, thy fortunes, thy estate,
And what she was that I resemble most?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: First look that no man see, or overhear us,
I think that shape was born to do me good.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Hast thou known one that did resemble me?

sp.speaker: Yong. Ar.
sp.l: I mistress, I cannot choose but weep
To call to mind the fortunes of her youth.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Tell me, of what estate or birth was she?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Born of good parents, and as well brought up.
Most fair, but not so fair as virtuous,
Happy in all things but her marriage.
Her riotous husband, which I weep to think,
By his lewd life made them both miscarry.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Why dost thou grieve at their adversities?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: O blame me not, that man my kinsman was,
nearer to me a kinsman could not be,
As near allied was that chaste woman too,
Nearer was never husband to his wife:
He whom I termed my friend, no friend of mine,
Proving both mine and his own enemy,
Poisoned his wife, o the time he did so,
Joyed at her death, inhumane slave to do so,
Exchanged her love for a base strumpet's lust;
Foul wretch, accursed villain, to exchange so.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: You are wise, and blessed, and happy to repent so,
But what became of him and his new wife?

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: O hear the justice of the highest heaven,
This strumpet in reward of all his love,
Pursues him for the death of his first wife,
And now the woeful husband languisheth,
Flies upon pursued by her fierce hate,
And now too late he doth repent her sin,
Ready to perish in his own despair,
Having no means but death to rid his care.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: I can endure no more but I must weep,
My blabbing tears cannot my counsel keep.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Why weep you mistress? if you had the heart
Of her whom you resemble in your face,
But she is dead, and for her death,
The sponge of either eye,
Shall weep red tears till every vain is dry.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Why weep you friend, your rainy drops keep
Repentance wipes away the drops of sin.
Yet tell me friend, he did exceeding ill,
A wife that loved and honoured him, to kill.
Yet say one like her, far more chaste than fair,
Bids him be of good comfort, not despair.
Her soul's appeased with her repentant tears,
Wishing he may survive her many years.
Fain would I give him money to supply
His present wants, but fearing he should fly,
And getting over to some foreign shore,
These rainy eyes should never see him more.
My heart is full, I can no longer stay,
But what I am my love must needs bewray.
Farewell good fellow, and take this to spend,
Say one like her commends her to your friend.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: No friend of mine, I was my own soul's foe
To murder my chaste wife, that loved me so.
In life she loved me dearer than her life,
What husband here, but would wish such a wife.
I hear the officers with hue and cry,
She saved my life but now, and now I die.
And welcome death, I will not stir from hence,
Death I deserved, I'll die for this offence.

div.stage: Enter Brabo with officers, Splay and Hugh.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Here is the murderer, and reason's man
You have the warrant: sirs lay hands on him,
Attach the slave, and lead him bound to death.

sp.speaker: Hu.
sp.p: No by my faith m. Brabo, you have the better heart, at least you should have: I am sure you have more iron and steel, than I have, do you lay hands upon him, I promise you I dare not.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Constables forward, forward officers,
I will not thrust my finger in the fire.
Lay hands on him I say, why step you back?
I mean to be the hindmost, least that any
Should run away and leave the rest in peril:
Stand forward, are you not ashamed to fear?

sp.speaker: Yon. Ar.
sp.l: Nay never strive, behold I yield myself,
I must commend your resolution,
That being so many and so weaponed,
Dare not adventure on a man unarmed.
Now lead me to what prison you think best,
Yet use me well, I am a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hue.
sp.p: Truly m. Arthur we will use you as well as heart can think, the justices sit today, and my mistress is chief, you shall command me.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What hath he yielded? if he had withstood us,
This curtle-axe of mine had cleft his head:
Resist he durst not when he once spied me.
Come lead him hence, how likest thou this sweet witch?
This fellow's death will make our mistress is rich.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: I say I care not whose dead or alive,
So by their lives or deaths, we two may thrive.

sp.speaker: Hue.
sp.l: Come bear him away.

div.stage: Enter justice reason, old Arthur, old Lusam.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Old m. Arthur and m. Lusam, so it is, that I have heard both your complaints, but understood neither, for you know legere et non intelligere negligere est.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I come for favour, as a father should,
Pitying the fall and ruin of his son.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: I come for justice, as a father should,
That hath by violent murder lost his daughter.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: You come for favour, and you come for justice,
Justice with favour is not partial,
And using that, I hope to please you both.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Good m. justice think upon my son.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: Good m. justice think upon my daughter.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Why so I do, I think upon them both,
But can do neither of you good:
For he that lives must die, and she that's dead,
Cannot be revived.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Lusam, thou seekst to rob me of my son, my only son.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: He robbed me of my daughter, my only daughter.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: And robbers are flat felons by the law.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Lusam, I say thou art a bloodsucker,
A tyrant, a remorseless cannibal:
Old as I am I'll prove it on thy bones.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Am I a bloodsucker or cannibal?
Am I a tyrant that do thirst for blood?

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: I if thou seekst the ruin of my son,
Thou art a tyrant and a bloodsucker.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: I if I seek the ruin of thy son I am indeed.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Nay more thou art a dotard.
And in the right of my accursed son,
I challenge thee the field, meet me I say
Tomorrow morning besides Islington,
And bring thy sword and buckler if thou dar'st.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Meet thee with my sword and buckler, there's my glove,
I'll meet thee to revenge my daughter's death.
Callst thou me dotard, though these threescore years,
I never handled weapon but a knife
To cut my meat, yet will I meet thee there.
God's precious call me dotard.

sp.speaker: Old Arthur.
sp.l: I have cause,
Just cause to call thee dotard, have I not?

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Nay that's another matter have you cause,
Than God forbid that I should take exceptions
To be called dotard of one that hath cause.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: My masters you must leave this quarrelling, for quarrellers are never at peace, and men of peace while they are at quiet are never quarrelling; so you whilst you fall into brawls, you cannot choose but jar. Here comes your son accused, and your wife the accuser: stand forth both. Hugh be ready with your pen and ink to take their examinations and confessions.

div.stage: Enter marry, Splay, Brabo, young Arthur, hue, and officers.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: It shall not need, I do confess the deed,
Of which this woman here accuseth me:
I poisoned my first wife, and for that deed
I yield me to the mercy of the law.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: Villain, thou meanst my only daughter,
And in her death deprivedst me of all joys.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I mean her, I do confess the deed,
And though my body taste the force of law,
Like an offender, on my knee I begs,
Your angry soul will pardon me her death.

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: Nay if he kneeling do confess the deed,
No reason but I should forgive her death.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: But so the law must not be satisfied,
Blood must have blood, and men must have death,
I think that cannot be dispensed withal.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: If all the world else would forgive the deed,
Yet would I earnestly pursue the law.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I had a wife would not have used me so,
The wealth of Europe could not hire her tongue,
To be offensive to my patient ears,
But in exchanging her, I did prefer
A devil before a saint, night before day,
Hell before heaven, and dross before tried gold,
Never was bargain with such damage sold.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: If you want witness to confirm the deed,
I heard him speak it, and that to his face
Before this presence I will justify,
I will not part hence till I see him swing.

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: I heard him too, pity but he should die,
And like a murderer be sent to hell,
To poison her, and make her belly swell.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why stay you then, give judgement on the slave,
whose shameless life deserves a shameful grave.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Death's bitter pangs are not so full of grief,
As this unkindness: every word thou speakst,
Is a sharp dagger thrust quite through my heart.
As little I deserve this at thy hands,
As my kind patient wife deserved of me,
I was her torment, God hath made thee mine,
Then wherefore at just plagues should I repine?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Where didst thou buy this poison? for such drugs
Are felony for any man to sell.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I had the poison of Aminadab,
But innocent man, he was not accessary
To my wife's death, I clear him of the deed.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: No matter, fetch him, fetch him, bring him
To answer to this matter at the bar:
Hue, take these officers and apprehend him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: I'll aid him too, the schoolmaster I see
Perhaps may hang with him for company.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: This is the day of Arthur's examination
And trial for the murder of his wife:
Let's hear how justice reason will proceed,
In censuring of his strict punishment.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Anselm content, let's thrust in among the throng.

div.stage: Enter Aminadab, brought in with officers.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: O dominae, what mean these knaves,
To lead me thus with bills and glaves?
O what example would it be,
To all my pupils for to see,
To tread their steps all after me:
If for some fault I hanged be:
Somewhat surely I shall mar,
If you bring me to the bar.
But peace, betake thee to thy wits,
for yonder justice reason sits.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Sir dad, sir Dab, here's one accuseth you
To give him poison being ill employed,
Speak how in this case you can clear yourself.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: Hei mihi, what should I say, the poison given I denay:
He took it perforce from my hands, and dominae why not I
Got it of a gentleman, he most freely gave it,
Ask he knew me, a means was only to have it.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis true I took it from this man perforce,
And snatched it from his hand by rude constraint,
Which proves him in this act not culpable.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I but who sold the poison unto him?
That must be likewise known, speak schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: A man verbosus, that was a fine generosus,
He was a great guller, his name I take to be fuller:
See where he stands that unto my hands conveyed a powder,
And like a knave sen her to her grave obscurely to shroud her.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Lay hands on him, are you a poison seller?
Bring him before us, sirrah what say you,
Sold you a poison to this honest man?

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: I sold no poison, but I gave him one
To kill his rats.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Ha, ha, I smell a rat.
You sold him poison then to kill his rats?
The word to kill, argues a murderous mind:
And you are brought in compass of the murder:
So set him by we will not hear him speak.
That Arthur fuller and the schoolmaster
Shall by the judges be examined.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Sir if my friend may not speak for himself
Yet let me his proceedings justify.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: What's he that will a murder justify?
Lay hands on him, lay hands on him I say,
For justifiers are all accessaries,
And accessaries have deserved to die.
A way with him, we will not hear him speak,
They all shall to the high commissioners.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Nay stay them, stay them yet a little while,
I bring a warrant to the contrary,
And I will please all parties presently.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I think my wife's ghost haunts me to my death,
Wretch that I was to shorten her life's breath.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: Whom do I see my son's wife?

sp.speaker: Old lus
sp.l: What my daughter?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Is it not mistress Arthur that we see,
That long since buried we supposed to be.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: This man is condemned for poisoning of his wife,
His poisoned wife yet lives, and I am she:
And therefore justly I release his bands.
This man for suffering him these drugs to take,
Is likewise bound, release him for my sake.
This gentleman that first the poison gave,
And this his friend to be released I crave.
Murder there cannot be where none is killed,
Her blood is saved whom you supposed was spilled.
Father in law I give you here your son,
The act's to do, which you supposed was done.
And father now joy in your daughter's life,
Whom heaven hath still kept to be Arthur's wife.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: O welcome, welcome, daughter now I see,
God by his power hath preserved thee.

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: And 'tis my wench whom I supposed was dead,
My joy revives, and my sad woe is fled.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: I know not what I am, nor where I am,
My souls transported to an ecstasy,
For hope and joy confound my memory.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What do I see, lives Arthur's wife again?
Nay then I labour for his death in vain.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: What secret force did in nature lurk;
That in her soul the poison would not work?

sp.speaker: Splay.
sp.l: How can it be the poison took no force?
She lives with that which would have killed a horse.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ar.
sp.l: Nay shun me not, be not ashamed at all,
To heaven not me, for grace and pardon fall.
Look on me Arthur, blush not at my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: Still fear and hope my grief and woe prolongs.
But tell me by what power thou didst survive?
With my own hands I tempered that vild draught
That sent thee breathless to thy grandsires grave,
If that were poison I received from him.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: That egonescio, but this dram
Received I of this gentleman.
The colour was to kill my rats,
But 'twas my own life to dispatch.

sp.speaker: Ful.
sp.l: Is it even so, than this ambiguous doubt
No man can better than myself decide.
That compound powder was of poppy made and mandrakes,
Of purpose to cast one into a sleep,
To ease the deadly pain of him whose leg
Should be sawed off, that powder gave I to the school master.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.l: And that same powder, even that idem,
You took from me the same per sidem:

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: And that same powder I commixed with wine,
Our godly knot of wedlock to untwine.

sp.speaker: Old Ar.
sp.l: But daughter who did take thee from thy grave?

sp.speaker: Old Lu.
sp.l: Discourse it daughter.

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: Nay that labour save.
Pardon me m. Arthur, I will now
Confess the former frailty of my love.
Your modest wife with words I tempted oft,
But neither ill I could report of you,
Nor any good I could forge for myself
Would win her to attend to my request:
Nay after death I loved her, in so much
That to the vault where she was buried,
My constant love did lead me thorough the dark,
There ready to have ta'en my last farewell,
The parting kiss I gave her I felt warm,
Briefly, I bore her to my mother's house,
Where she hath since lived the most chaste and true,
That since the world's creation eye did view.

sp.speaker: Young Ar.
sp.l: My first wife stand you here, my second there,
And in the midst myself: he that will choose
A good wife from a bad, come other of me
That have tried both, in wealth and misery.
A good wife will be careful of her fame,
Her husband's credit, and her own good name:
And such art thou. A bad wife will respect
Her pride, her lust, and her good name neglect,
And such art thou. A good wife will be still
Industrious , apt to do her husband's will.
But a bad wife, cross, spiteful and madding,
Never keep home, but always be a gadding:
And such art thou. A good wife will conceal
Her husband's dangers, and nothing reveal
That may procure him harm, and such art thou.
But a bad wife corrupts chaste wedlock's vow.
On this hand virtue, and on this hand sin,
This who would strive to lose, or this to win?
Here lives perpetual joy, here burning woe,
Now husbands choose on which hand you will go.
Seek virtuous wives, all husbands will be blessed,
Fair wives are good, but virtuous wives are best,
They that my fortunes will peruse, shall find
No beauties like the beauty of the mind.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
